description:
This place is crackin on weekends, and the bartenders here are super knowledgeable (well at least the one tending us is). We got an extra dry martini with The Botanist Gin, and oh boy, it was delicious. I hate olives so I got mine with a twist. :)

There used to be Deer Hunter in the back but it's no longer there. There is a pool table though, and some other old school arcade games!
author: Michael K.

description:
Best bar in the neighborhood.

Dog-friendly

Good drinks

Usually great service (sometimes they completely skip me, and the wait is terribly long)
author: Michelle B.

description: Rude doorman (really, really rude jerk of a doorman!), bartenders who don't seem to be particularly happy to work there, watered down, overpriced drinks, in an uninviting setting -- why anyone would rate this s**t-hole with anything more than one star is beyond belief.
author: Gina F.

description:
- Decent place for drinks after work
- DOG FRIENDLY! You don't need to feel bad about leaving your buddy at home anymore because they can come inside with you :)
- Variety of beers on tap
- A few wines available
- Interesting cocktail menu $10+
- Pool table inside
- They sell jerky. Yum! Get some whiskey and jerky  

*NOTE: A 20% charge will be added to your bill if you leave your card/overnight
author: Saachi G.

description:
This spot is my friend's "neighborhood bar," so it was fun to see where she hangs out. I'm not sure I would have had this spot on my radar if it hadn't been for her, but it has a lot of great things going for it.

They have a decent cocktail menu, and pricing is competitive. The beer list is small but nicely curated, including a good portion of local stuff.

Definitely on the louder side of bars, but we could hear a pretty amusing Valentine's Day playlist.

Good for groups. Don't forget to look up!
author: Jess L.

description:
4.5 stars. I've found my new favorite dog-friendly neighborhood bar! It's 10 more minutes walking from my place than Bar Basic, but I'm sure Oz (our husky puppy) appreciates the extra exercise. I should, too.

I've never been to a bar where the customers loved Oz so much. It was adorable, and it warms my heart to meet other dog lovers. It was pretty crowded when my friend and I arrived around 5:00 PM but we found places to stand at the end of the bar by the pool table. 

At first, we tied Oz to the pipe underneath the bar, then we let him roam around when we saw he didn't cause too much trouble. Unfortunately he ran out the door at one point and almost into the street, so we'll be way more careful next time. Yikes!

Anyways, the drinks here are great, from cocktails to beers. The vibe is laid-back, the bartenders are super friendly, and there's a good rotation of customers so you'll usually find somewhere to sit eventually. And there's a pool table with a good amount of space around the edge so no one gets impaled by a cue stick.

I'd love to come back again in the future and hope we meet other dog (and human) friends! Sometimes it's stressful to bring the dog anywhere, but everyone at Bloodhound made it such a relaxing experience, so thank you.
author: Stefanie C.

description: The best greyhounds with fresh squeezed grapefruit juice and dog friendly. I love this place, just before it gets too crowded.
author: Jackie S.

description:
What a great neighborhood bar!  I will admit that when we walked in, I thought "oh no, it's a dive bar.  This is going to be gross."  Not at all.  It is a super laid back bar with a divey feel but really good drinks and amazing service.

We were there on a Friday around happy hour.  Only one bartender and he was awesome.  I don't know how one person could handle so many people and make all of these specialty cocktails.  If it were me and I had that crowd by myself, I would be handing out cans of Bud Light and only that all night long.

Good craft beer available.  Good wine.  Fun cocktails.

I wish we had not made reservations for dinner immediately following or we would have stayed all night.
author: Angela B.

description:
Nice place.
Nice people there.
Nice bartenders.
The people I was with liked the cocktails.
I like lager, but Buzz Light only had a nice flavor.
Nice is boring.
I would try something new instead of coming back.
author: Ken K.

description:
THEY NO LONGER HAVE BUCK HUNTER... sad :(

Four stars still for the same reasons in my previous review.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Three separate times in one week i went to this bar, having relocated for work, to SoMa. On each occasion I had three different bartenders... on each occasion i was charged a different prices for the exact same drink. 

The first bartender knew the trade and worked it well, an empty bar but a lot of lively conversation. Drink price $6 per.

The second night, a packed bar for an event. Regardless of this, the bartender was very attentive. Drink price $8 per.

My final visit. Dead bar, and bartender couldn't spell conversational if you asked them. Drink price $10 per.

This place is a scam and i don't know if the owners dont care or if some bartenders know how to treat new regulars well and others don't, either way neither me or any of my work colleagues (we all just moved here) will attend this bar again.
author: Andrew B.

description: Great vibe with lots of space and windows, super bartender, and fantastic beer choices.
author: DJ D.

description:
Bloodhound is awesome! The boy told me it's "one of those bars where the bartender actually takes several minutes to make your drink," and it lived up to it. That said, wasn't completely thrilled with what I ordered, but the boy was kind enough to switch with me.

I enjoyed the second drink much more -- it was a mix of something with Sierra Nevada (I believe it had Sunset in the name) and it was great. Tasted like a more citrus-y hefeweizen. I wanted to try the Bloodhound but didn't get around to it. Next time!

Drinks in hand, we hung around one of the nice wooden tables for a bit. It was almost completely empty at first (10:30ish?), but the place filled up by midnight.

And YAY - photo booth in back!
author: Nic Z.

description: Let me tell you, the bar tender tonight is a serious Rockstar. It is SLAMMED. Wall to wall at 6:00 pm and this dude is by.him.self. no one is waiting. Drinks are perfect. This guy deserves a raise or something. Joe. He is awesome. Joe for President 2020.
author: Andrea K.

description:
Pros: about two blocks from my work. One of the few cocktail bars in the area that opens at 4 rather than 5. Happy Hour from 4-7 Monday - Friday. Decent comfortable seating. Full bar, nice draft beer selection and pretty much any spirit to make cocktails. 

Cons: One bartender for Happy Hour in SOMA? Seemed to get a bit overwhelmed so service was slow...Also, I do have a pet peeve when the bar is busy and I am waiting to order but the bartender is over on the other end taking shots....Gets pretty busy with the SOMA crowd by 5-530, so get there early if possible to stake out a seat. The menu wasn't anything too exciting or innovative, got the New Fashioned... nothing really "new" about it tasted like a standard old fashioned to me.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Finished the night of my bachelorette party here, just cause there was a line at Raven next door and we were in the mood to wind down, not feel suffocated somewhere crowded.

Had a "Mexican firing squad," which was tequila, lime, grenadine, and bitters. Perfect name for the drink. It was like a margarita with a little kick to it.

Plenty of places to sit, which I enjoyed. Nice place.
author: Angela H.

description: Nice little bar, they have a pretty solid moscow mule (with copper mugs and all!). There's also pool, some little arcade games, and ample bar and table space. Cool place to meet up with some friends for a drink!
author: Nerissa C.

description: Okay neighborhood bar, nothing more. Short list of cocktails, about $12, short list of beers and very short list of wines. Torn up leatherette sofa, long bar, and a few high top tables. Mostly middle age clientele. Don't bother if you don't like country music.
author: Jojo S.

description: Great place, really cool looking. I love the way it's laid out. I had a great time here last night and I'll definitely be visiting this bar again
author: Karen C.

description: Louie! Great bartender!!!! Had a great time on Presidents' Day! Since Raven was closed!!
author: Joseph M.

description: Was a great atmosphere and the drinks were mixed perfectly. I will definitely be back.
author: Kevin B.

description: Good staff that knows how to make great cocktails. The moscow mule is actually on tap and it's the best I've ever had!
author: James D.

description: Bloodhound is a classic SF Bar  in my books, they have everything you could ever need.  Amazing cocktails, pool table, Pinball,  and a very unique photo booth to match.  It is a must check out, and is super chill for happy hour before the late night crowds.
author: Graham L.

description: Dog friendly, not too loud for conversation, comfortable neighborhood bar with good cocktails but a somewhat limited beer selection. I'll definitely use it as a place to meet up with friends again in the future.
author: Tom K.

description: One of my favorite neighborhood bars in Mid-Market. They make an amazing Gold Rush here bc the bartenders are very meticulous when it comes to crafting cocktails. You also get to walk past all the people waiting in line for nearby nightclubs and only then do you truly appreciate your decision to come here and enjoy a drink in this classy but chill bar.
author: Tiffany T.

description: A lively bar, perfect for a quick drink or to meet a Tinder date! Bartenders were nice and helped me right away. I thought their drink selection was a good one--they offered sparkling wine (my favorite!).
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: Great drinks, great service, AMAZING Photo Booth. Probably the best in the city!
author: Christine C.

description:
Bouncer communicates in sign language while talking on his phone.
(11/9/2016 10:20 PM just in case management reads this.)

A friend and I decided to have a beer on a Wednesday night 
and as I presented my ID to the bouncer, he apparently gave a "thumbs up" about as high as my midsection. I'm 5'6. 

Me, as I feel it's polite to make eye contact to whomever I'm doing business with, did not see this "thumbs up" and the bouncer smartass-ingly asks, "do you not see my thumb?" 

No, I did not see your thumb. Out of all the places for me to look other than making eye contact would my sight move to your thumb placed no higher than a legally considered dwarf?

Okay, one bad encounter but whatever, I let it slide even though I can get a drink elsewhere.

On to the bartender! 

She makes a cocktail RIGHT IN FRONT OF ME even though the drink was for the person sitting two feet to my right. 

I make small talk as she's awkwardly face to face with me so I ask, "hey, is that an Old Fashion cocktail?" and she gave me a snobbish "yes" like my presence was a nuisance to her almighty being. 

Guess I didn't read the situation that a bartender needs her full concentration stirring liquor in a glass. It's not like she did a "4-count free pour" to need all that concentration since homegirl used a jigger to measure her liquor. 

Yeahhh...4 counts, jiggers, knowing the cocktail she was making, is why I'm writing this drawn out review. 

As a former bartender, I understand customer service is top priority especially on slow nights when an establishment can convert a passerby to a loyal customer. In this case, bouncer & bartender failed and gets this 1 star review. Why was this bartender a snob? Why does this bouncer think a thumbs up three feet off the ground is the norm for people to look in nightlife scene? With this review, I too am holding up a finger; but it's not my thumb. ;)

Advice to management: 
Train your staff to create a welcoming watering hole. I know how difficult it is on slow nights when there's not enough customers to get the rush of mixing cocktails left and right to a crowded bar but damn, a slither of customer service would've been nice. 

Keep your hoity-toity 2x2 inch single cube ice cubes in your hipster posh mason jars - we bought the top shelf stuff somewhere else since the staff at Bloodhound tonight didn't deserve another penny from us.
author: John C.

description:
Came by yesterday to watch the Giants game before having dinner nearby. I like the vibe of the place. Very low key. Not a lot of people while we were here. A few at the bar, tables, etc, which probably added to the reason I had a great time. I hate being at crowded bars. There are only a few TVs, so I wouldn't call this a sports bar by any means. But it was nice to watch the game while throwing back a couple drinks.

Side note: There are birds painted on the ceiling. Maybe they were stenciled, but they were birds! I'm scared of birds so this was not a welcome decoration. So if you're scared of birds like me, don't look up!
author: Elena N.

description: Came here last week with some coworkers for a goodbye party.. there was enough space for all of us and the bartenders were attentive and quick. No complaints
author: Alyssa H.

description: Drinks were good but the service was only OK. Good place for large groups. Comfortable vibes.
author: Joni W.

description: I just hosted a private New Year's Eve party for 110 people at Bloodhound and it was AWESOME! Would definitely recommend renting out this space for any private party. Jacobo, the event manager, was super responsive to emails and helped make sure all the details were taken care of before the event. John, the owner, was also very helpful. He met me ahead of time to show us the space and was very flexible with our requests.  The guests enjoyed the arcade games, pool, and photobooth on site and we brought in our own DJ. We definitely kept the bar tenders busy with the open bar they provided, but they did an amazing job with quick service and wonderful cocktails. I would definitely have another party here, or just stop by for a drink!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: "Call your credit card company..." One of the bartenders overcharged me, having thrown on two additional mixed drinks I never order! I'd only had 2 beers at this point, so by no means did I forget what I'd ordered. I asked him to take those extra drinks I never purchased off and he refused. I told him I wasn't going to pay for them and he said, "Not my problem, file a claim with your credit card company, but you aren't getting your card back until you sign for your drinks". Eventually he did remove one of the drinks and said, "let's call it even". He just wanted me to leave. I paid, about $20 extra, and left. I will never be going back here again and recommend this place figure out how to track who buys what. No, I won't be filing a claim with my credit card company because of the hassle, but be warned this has happened and can happen again here. The one star is for the pool table which was a nice touch to the atmosphere.
author: Alan W.

description: This, they tell me, is a "New Fashioned." Interesting group. Solid mix of "new" & "old" San Francisco. #Bloodhound #SoMa
author: Nick S.

description: Not much seating. There's a pool table, and a vendor who sells pulled pork with mac & cheese that's pretty decent. The beer selections are okay, but it's weird drinking from a thick, stubby mason jar.
author: Kimberly H.

description: This place is great! From the old school rap/hip hop music, to the awesome staff, to the beer/craft cocktail selection, to the decor.  Wasn't overly crowded when I went yesterday (Friday) at 5pm. There were a couple dogs chilling with their owners, so that means it is pet friendly. As a pet owner, this is a thumbs up! They had a good beer (including stouts and sours, my favorites) and cocktail selection. The bartender was very nice and knowledgable offering tastings of some of the beers he thought I might like. If I lived in the area this place would definitely be one of my regular spots! Highly recommended.
author: Michelle W.

description:
What a great neighborhood bar. And here I'd all but given up on all these transplants creating any semblance of a "community" in SoMa.

Great beer selection (love the Nitro stout... please never leave me), clean and level pool table (for a buck AND you don't need to bug the bar for quarters), Big Buck Hunter, and dozed of dimly-lit and very comfortable places to sit and talk with your friends (who happen to be your neighbors).
author: Mike V.

description: Cozy bar off Folsom. For some reason it gives you an Old Time western feel, but I have to admit drinks are amazing. I order food from Ubereats and they allowed me to bring it in while I had drinks.
author: Koby G.

description:
SHOUTOUT TO RUDY!! Awesome bartender, super nice and freakin' COOL. (Don't wave your hand around like an IDIOT either trying to get ANY bartenders attention! *RUDE*)

Time for some drinks for the birthday boy! He decided on this bar because I guess it is sister bars with another bar him and his friends frequent. 
It's hot up in hurr! And it's busy! I asked my friend if they have AC?? She said Nooo place really does, look, the WINDOWS are OPEN. ALRIGHTY THEN. SO I sweat it out. 
They have a LARGE liquor selection.. Just not the type of liquor I drink. I'm a Vodka girl and the only flavors they have are like Tito's Citrus and Orange-type. First I tried the Citrus-y one. NOT A FAN!! I moved on to the Orange-y one. MUCH better. 
I get wasted. And I have fun. 
The end.
author: Jenny D.

description:
Stopped in after getting all boozy at Coqueta for a company lunch. I'm a little surprised the bouncer let me in considering my general state and my expired ID, but honestly, who's going to turn down a girl in a plastic silver tiara that says Birthday Girl with 10 people in tow?? It happens, judge away.

After lounging on one of the couches with some friends, three waters deep, I started to feel like a real human and sipped on a Mason jar of beer. Sadly passing off shots of Fernet and Jameson, I staggered around the bar for hugs while I admired the blackbirds painted on the ceiling, low-key lighting, and pretty mirrors placed around the bar. It's a smaller locale, and I was worried about the twenty or so friends I had showing up later in the evening, but all turned out well. 

Everyone was being abnormally nice to me, and then I remembered it was my birthday and I was wearing a ridiculous birthday girl crown. I suppose this occasion was such fun mostly because all my friends showed up and the whole bar sang happy birthday to me, but I truly want to go back when my head is right and I can take in the full effect of the place. Until then, here's 5 Stars for putting up with my white-girl wasted a$s on a special night.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Loved this place. Nice vibe. Well-laid out. The bartenders were great and had good advice when we asked for it. They had a great selection of whiskeys but did not have cream to make a White Russian. Small thing I guess. 

Love this place!
author: Brian B.

description:
Not bad, not great. My friend JUST missed the cut off to get into Raven for free, and we were really just going to go for a couple of drinks...so we walked outside, and promptly into Bloodhound. This...seems quite typical.

Crowd...young. Overwhelmingly white. Couple of Asians thrown here and there. No other POC's around, unless you count security. 

Ambiance...is ok. A little dark (who doesn't like to drink in a dark place??), and area is set up so that people crowd away from the bar. Nice. It might be good to remove a couple of chairs so people are forced to go away after getting drinks, or people won't lean over groups to get a drink, but who am I to judge. 

Staff were friendly, and quick about getting drinks. The drinks themselves are a bit pricey ($10+ for like, 5 oz of liquid) but well made in general. 

Upon leaving, we walk by a guy super drunk and his 2 friends taking care of him. Says the friend, "don't worry, he's ok."  Says me, "I couldn't really care less."
author: Lily W.

description:
Great place to come play pool and kick back with some friends. 

Can get pretty busy at night on the weekends or game days but the bar service stays moving and the crowd stays cool. 

Happy Hour is great but the fancy drinks stay expensive.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Great drinks, friendly staff, skilled bartenders.  Loved that the bartenders had a good rapport going between them and worked together to make sure everyone was taken care of.  Vibe is good- came on a Friday night and it was busy but not too crowded.  Good music.

Absolutely repulsive bathroom (cannot overstate this).  I totally had to hover and the floor was wet with all sorts of paper products all over the place.  Despite that, I would return!
author: Sarah R.

description:
It was around 10pm on a wednesday night, and hubby and I wanted to go out for a couple of drinks. It was very crowded here (for what I'm used to, but I'm sure it wasn't that bad for SF), and it was a little difficult getting to the bar and trying to get the attention of the bartenders --partly because of the crowd and partly because I was a foot shorter than everyone else. However, the bartenders are very attentive, and I eventually got a drink. They have a small but good selection of beers, and mixed drinks. My hubby and I were pleasantly surprised by their recommendations (the bartenders are very knowledgeable about their drinks), and they kept checking up on us as our drinks got low. 

They were out of the Old Speckled Hen beer, but the bartender recommended a dark nitro beer instead (I think it was Deschutes Armory XPA). It was very tasty (I like dark beers). Hubby was excited that they had a cocktail with pisco, so he ordered that. It was very strong, yet refreshing. The whisky drinks also looked really good, as the bartenders made them with such care and precision, so hubby got one of those too.

Tip: the crowd thinned out a lot as it got closer to midnight. By 10:30/11-ish, we got seats at the bar, which is why we had such good service. 

Despite the tight space and crowd, the decor alone is worth a visit. I would've liked to return for drinks earlier in the day too, so as to avoid the crowd, but alas, so much to do in so little time!
author: NY C.

description:
Good. Went on Friday after work and it was fairly crowded at the bar (we waited about 5 min for seats). They also seemed to have a shortage of menus because I had to ask someone for theirs and returned the favor a few minutes later for another person.

Cocktails were tasty though not as imaginative as a place like Tradition or Swig. Bartenders were just okay, not overly friendly and took a while to get their attention for our second round.

Decor is really great. They take cards. Pretty loud so I wouldn't recommend for a first date/catching up with a friend. It's not close to my apartment and it's a solid 15 min walk from my office so I likely won't return unless I find myself in this area again.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Love the vibe and the quality of the drinks in this place. Feels a bit like an old hunting lodge (dark paneling, some taxidermy) but nothing too stuffy, and plenty of room to mill about. We sat at one of the tables opposite the bar and didn't have any trouble hearing each other.

I gave the bartender my order (4 diff drinks) and despite having to finish up someone else's fairly complicated drink order she kept everything straight and got all our drinks done right - thought that was nice. There's a long list of prohibition-era/style drinks - pretty much any kind of alcoholic concoction. I kept it simple with a 209 & tonic and the proportions were right.

Was pretty crowded when I was here so had to keep an eagle eye on the chairs we were using lest some hoser came over and stole one if someone got up to get another round/use the facilities.

Only downside from my perspective, and maybe all of San Francisco is like this, but if I was a lady I might have been a little creeped out by the stalker-ish vibe of all the dudes hovering around just waiting for their "moment". Hint: it's not gonna happen, move on.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Really solid cocktails for cheaper than SF market rate.

I came on a Wednesday evening and both bartenders were friendly and carefully measured out the ingredients and actually tasted the cocktails before serving it to the customer.  I had 2 cocktails:

Brooklyn ($10) - a superior version of a Manhattan!  Served in a coupe, rye-based, and used French vermouth (dry), so it was more bitter than sweet.  Also, the orange peel essence pleasantly shone through. 

Woodsman ($9) - like an old fashioned but spiked with Fernet.  I got it with scotch and was very pleased.

They don't have the house-infused spirits and herbal tinctures that are trendy nowadays.  But they make excellent drinks with classic ingredients for a moderate price.  Why haven't I frequented Bloodhound more up until now??
author: Beatrice W.

description:
I wasn't the biggest fan of Bloodhound, but it really depends on what you're looking for in a bar. I came in on a Thursday night with co-workers, and the place was 75% full, and also almost as hot as sauna inside. Although I was impressed by the variety of whiskies/scotches/bourbons/alcohol in general they had on the shelves, I was yawning status from how bored I was just standing there in a group people watching. There was nothing of interest going on, unless you want to play video games on their TV or try to play pool on the table that people use to rest against. You could barely hear the music playing in the background, and there is no dance floor here. So, if you enjoy just standing all night and chit chatting with your friends and/or strangers, this is the bar for you. If you're looking to dance or do something aside from standing around and drinking, then head elsewhere. 

At least it's modern/clean inside and there is no cover (Thursday night anyway), but parking can be difficult in this area and there is only one bathroom for the ladies.
author: Amy D.

description:
So, I've never had a time where I felt the urge to ask for the manager of a bar. Today, at bloodhound, I asked for the name of the manager of the bar and the bouncer, along with his buddies (one a bartender at the bar) loudly chanted (in my face) for 5 minutes, "his name is John FUCK YOU."

So, if you want to go to a bar that would utterly disrespect you for giving a "weird look", go check out this one!

The only reason to go to this bar is to wait for the line to die down next door at Raven.  I was really excited to check out this bar with a group of 5 sober people (meaning did not drink at all before) and was turned away at the door for being "disrespectful". I understand that bouncers have all the power to turn people away with reasonable cause but I've never experienced this sense of discrimination and utter condemnation.  I was in such disbelief as to why the bouncer refused to let my friend in so I asked for an explanation.

The bouncer, word for word, told me that my friend simply, "gave him a weird look", at which point a bartender and third person, who was chatting with the bouncer, decided to verbally assault me outside of bar. 

I highly doubt that it is reason enough for a bouncer to rudely and loudly degrade a person by raising their voice and prohibiting them to enter a bar because he/she felt the person trying to get in "gave them a weird look". Additionally, it is not okay that the bouncer continued to verbally attack me and allow the friends of the bouncer to abuse and assault people he turned away from the door. 

After viewing the negative comments about this place, it is not surprising that I received this response from this bar.
author: Janet H.

description: Really liked the decor in this place but it was way too packed at 9pm to barely get in or get a drink. Shoulder to shoulder with everyone. We came with a pub crawl to play pool but no way that was happening. I'd like to return maybe when it's not so busy as it looked like a nice place and their Moscow mules on tap ($12) were yummy. No cover to get in at 9pm.
author: Ranee W.

description:
This place is bomb! Not only are their drinks plentiful and stiff, but you see a glimpse of the eclectic SF scene here: a guy in a suit, casual hipsters, and yuppies.

But the best part about this place is the fact that they ALLOW dogs! It really brought out the creepy-dog-lady in me ... I was eyeing all the dogs in the room. There was a 3month old yorkie pup sitting at the end of the couch, and a small terrier-mix right across the room ^__^ bliss.

Gotta thank my buddy's buddy for recommending us to this secret gem.
author: Rosie C.

description:
Cool vibe. Was a great place for after dinner drinks. Wasn't too crowded after 7 midweek.
Pretty comfortable, awesome decor. 
Loved our drinks.
author: Amy O.

description:
Went to Bloodhound with my mates after hanging out at Oddjob for a bit. Grady over at Oddjob sold it hard so we had to go check it out.

The environment is pretty chill and it's a great place to come and enjoy yourself. Toucan is the man! He whipped up some drinks for us as we sat at the bar and shot the shit. No complaints here!

Overall, rad place. Will be looking to come back soon.
author: Jared W.

description: I am totalllllly NOT a bar person whatsoever. I'd rather go somewhere where there is music playing or go to a restaurant and grab drinks. However, this past weekend I had a pleasant experience here. Getting drinks was simple, well-ventilated bar (our table was right next to the windows), really good noise level - easy to have a convo with our friends. All in all, a good atmosphere and crowd.
author: Raji R.

description:
Professional mixologists. Straight-up booze alchemists. They have a specials menu and all of them are just...fantastic. I'm not sure I've ever had such well-crafted cocktails as I had from Bloodhound. 

They're pricey...but worth it. It's also pretty spacious in there. I will most likely go back!
author: Julia D.

description:
I might not get wild at bars these days, but do I enjoy drinking in the wild or in the very least, at a bar decorated in haute hunting lodge fashion replete with taxidermy dripping from the walls?

You bet.

Between Bloodhound's bevy of handsomely-bearded men, strong cocktail & craft beer programs, laid back vibe, and plethora of patrons sporting plaid flannel shirts, it's no surprise that I really dig it.

Is there anything else to say? Nope - all my bases are covered at Bloodhound. Arm-twisting not necessary!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
One of my favorite Soma bars, Bloodhound always impresses with its laid-back vibe, good drinks, and a nice mix of cool people you wouldn't mind striking a conversation with. 

I love the beers on tap here; nice selection ranging from Scrimshaw to Franziskaner to the Old Speckled Hen but their cocktails probably steal the limelight. I quite enjoy the Bloodhound #2 and Negronis. Friendly bartenders concoct cocktails fairly efficiently here and they're good. It can get packed but it's a wonderful spot to savor your drink when you come during off hours like Saturday afternoon. Off hours also makes for pretty interesting people watching here. Once saw a greyhound meet up. Yes greyhounds, not bloodhounds I know. That would be just too matchy-matchy. 

Stop by, grab a communal long table, enjoy drinks and conversation, and shoot some video game deer or pool. Whatever you do, it's probably going to be a fun stop at Bloodhound.
author: Jon L.

description:
Bloodhound is a bar that I wish I went to more often. They've got a great selection of beer, great decor, and friendly service.

The best part about this bar? It's DOG FRIENDLY! Also love how they have a hunting arcade game right by the pool table.

Get here early, however. Tables and seating are limited - it's not a terrible thing, just a minor inconvenience.

Dogs, a pool table, a hunting game, and mason jars - overall very awesome.
author: Nate W.

description: I've been here before on a busy weekend night and it wasn't my cup of tea... too busy, crowded, loud but, we met a friend here on a weekend night, he loves this place, it's his go to! We made friends with the bartenders, they made recommendations for scotch and I commented I wished I enjoyed drinking the boozier cocktails, because the old fashioned smelled so good. The bartender made a recommendation and let me taste the liquor before she made my drink... The drink kicked my ass but it tasted great!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I came here to grab a drink for two before an event at 1015 Folsom down the street. The music was so good here that I almost did not want to leave. They were playing hip hop and "ratchet" music which made it the perfect place to get pumped up.

At first glance the bar may seem very hipster or pretentious but it was actually really down to earth. The bartenders were all really approachable and the drinks were delicious! It was pretty packed but it was pretty easy to find a place to sit.

I would definitely come back here when in the area and would bring out of town guests as well! Great vibes, tunes, and people.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I haven't written up my San Francisco trip reviews yet, mainly because they would all be glowing but I have to talk about our experience here.  It is a dive bar close to where I am staying that yelp pointed out and I was excited to try.  Good beer selection? Nice whiskey cocktails? Funky dive bar decor? I was all about it.

Unfortunately we got treated to the worst service Ive ever gotten at a bar.  After announcing a premature closing time we were singled out from the other patrons still finishing and rudely asked to leave.  We tried to finish our drinks and a friend asked why they were closing early and the bouncer just took his drink and told him he was done. Of course I was like...what the hell man and was then threatened to have my drink taken away.  We were flabbergasted but all the the bartender did was chuckle and say he said they were closing.

Never gotten such rude service and they were clearly just amused at how upset it made us and could not care less.  Thought this bar would be right up my alley but it has been the worst experience of my vacation.  I would stay away unless you are okay with a place that would treat its customers so poorly.
author: Anthony M.

description:
I've been here a few times now and I have to say - each time has been met with a good evening.  The last time I stopped in was during happy hour on a Thursday, and enjoyed the cuffs and buttons cocktail.  We found an open stool at the bar, placed our orders, had a few sips, turned around and found an open table.  Moments later a tiny dog was in the bar, and then a huge great Dane.  If only one had been a bloodhound.

It's dark, laid back and riddled with savory specialty drinks.
author: Michelle C.

description:
5.17.13 The décor was woodsy? I'm not sure how to describe it, there were birds on the ceiling, antler chandelier, shooting game at the end of the bar and drinks served out of a mason jar. This is a laid back type of a bar and most of all their drinks were super duper strong. I came here twice and tried at least four drinks and ack, it was hard to swallow. I guess for some people it's a good thing but for someone like me I prefer to enjoy my drink but wasn't able to. I have probably ordered the wrong drinks. Other people seem to like their drinks so I'll leave as that..

The next time I order I will say "On the weak side please" LOL.
author: Mia L.

description:
Things I Like To Do Here:

1. Get down with the jukebox.
2. Drink the fabulously tasty New Fashioned.
3. Rock out on the pool table.
4. Get embarrassed at Buck Hunter (in a bar decorated like a hunting lodge). 

Basically, Bloodhound is a good bar. I'd write more, but Bloodhound seems to always be our 3rd or 4th stop, and it gets a bit hazy.
author: Peter D.

description: Nice bar. The decor is nice and it's not super divey. Prices are very reasonable too. And icing on the cake - there's buck hunter in the back.
author: Sherry L.

description: Cool spot but staff is so rude. Sat for 10 mins waiting to get a drink. Walked past me 3 times to other ends of the bar. Rolled their eyes when special requests on drinks. Asking for "splashes" of soda in our drinks. Angry at life???
author: Natalie S.

description:
The bar is nice and roomy, but it never feels welcoming.  Maybe that's part of the Hipster motif it has, but I've never felt like it was a fun place.  That being said, the drinks are really good.  I've had the New Fashioned and the Bloodhound (with Tequila).  The first being their take on the old fashioned and it lives up to expectations.  The Bloodhound is a like Grey Hound with you choice of alcohol.  I like Grapefruit juice so i liked this drink a lot.  

It as a pool table and hunting game in the back, both require money to play.  Service is okay, but not the most friendly.  Music in background is an eclectic mix of everything from Rap to Indie Rock.
author: Veasna H.

description:
We were going to watch a show at 1015 Folsom for a friend's birthday, and decided to grab drinks and hang out a bit before the show at Bloodhound.

The first thing I noticed was DOGS. This place is dog friendly! Although I don't think bars are the best place for dogs, it wasn't too crowded here - even though it was a Friday night - and I felt okay for my four legged friends. 

Onto more relevant things: 

The second thing I appreciated was the music wasn't too loud, which was awesome because I was actually able to have conversations with friends before the show. There was ample seating space if you wanted it, but most people were standing around. 

I wasn't drinking but sampled a few sips of friend's drinks, and they were delicious. Although, I didn't get the sense the drinks were too strong so it's not the best spot if you're really trying to pregame. 

I would recommend bloodhound if you want a chill spot to actually socialize, enjoy drinks and get some good dog vibes!
author: Vrinda G.

description:
It's my local watering hole. But that's like saying it's my local bead store. How many times have I been here even though I live a couple of blocks away? Oh...twice. The number of bars I've Yelped is paltry because: (1) I'm not that much of a drinker, or (2) when I do drink, I make a serious commitment and then can't remember why my Hanes boxers are on top of my head. 

As bars go, Bloodhound is relaxing if you can find an empty set of seats. That's a big "if" during the weekends because it attracts a lot of the young urban professionals who live in the surrounding lofts. I don't think much of the hipsters come here - which is a blessing - but I'm also not big on selfish, privileged, white-collar morons who hoard seats and then promptly ignore you as they tap pretentiously on their iPhones. Still, there is a hunting lodge vibe that's hard to resist. 

Moose antler chandeliers. Georgia O'Keefe-type skeletal animal heads. Faded slat-board walls. Pool table, of course. And a nice long bar that manages to be packed no matter how eagle-eyed you get in trying to find a stool. I've had the Planter's Punch here, which is unsurprisingly a fruity drink, all dark rum and pineapple juice, but somehow it fits the laid-back setting on the stretch of Folsom that's slowly becoming a dipso-ghetto. 

DRINKS - 4 stars...good for a parched throat 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...hunting lodge-meets-yuppie haven...does anyone say 'yuppie' anymore? 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pours 'em up just fine 
TOTAL - 4 stars...get here before or after the evening rush to take maximum advantage
author: Ed U.

description:
Fell in love instantly with the decor. Made me regret texting all my friends about this awesome new bar I found by serving me the worst mojito of my life. Regained my trust when another bartender made me a drink and told me he would make me a new one if I didn't like the first one. QUIT PLAYING GAMES WITH MY HEART. 

Also is this a gay bar because if it isn't then it should be.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
The crowd at Bloodhound is fat chicks and short dudes, not what anybody is looking for.
I've been here to Bloodhound a couple times and it's really the sort of place I wouldn't spend anymore time than I had to. The bartenders aren't particularly nice or good. A lot of attitude and more interest  what's going on behind the bar than with what's going on in front.
The space is big, party big but inspired by nothing more than SF bar trends. Maybe that's the metta gag, it's a San Francisco bar theme bar. There's something about this place that makes one want to leave
author: Tommy W.

description:
Great bar in SOMA. I love the decor and space here. It reminds me a little bit of Churchill in The Castro. The crowd is well mixed and the drinks are strong. They have cider here so I was happy about that. Cocktails were a bit on the pricey side.

And if you like lard, you can have some pork rinds with your adult beverage.

Gather some friends for a fun night and include this on your hop around the city.
author: Amy J.

description: Standard bar with craft cocktail attempts. Went mid-week and it was pretty empty, the Warriors game was on though. The bar was expecting a big party of 60 to show up which decreased to 8 people, so the staff was pretty bummed out. The bartender was not attentive and when she did address us, she was definitely not happy. Drinks were ok. I'd probably only go to this bar if I lived near it and wanted a easy place to drink.
author: Zara S.

description:
I love me some Bloodhound.

Nice low-key spot. Rustic, hip space reminiscent of a hunting lodge; reclaimed wood tables, deer antlers and a pool table in the back. Look up and you'll see birds painted on the ceiling. Fantastic. Lots of seating available. Bartenders are friendly.

Great selection of beer on tap. Drafts served in mason jars. $5 Old Speckled Hen!  Wonderful whiskey selection. For cocktails, I recommend the Recoil or the New Fashioned, both bourbon drinks.

Dog friendly! Awesome.
author: Ashley K.

description: This is a cool place. You can tell by the wall to wall people that ar here most nights. They have a really cool drink list. The best part really is that they have pool and a cool hunting arcade game. Its very Montana meets SF feeling. Good drinks, great for large groups, but crowded...like everywhere!
author: Kari G.

description: With Raven right next door, this is a good place to kickstart the festivities after dinner. It's a bit dim and can get loud, but if you're planning on clubbing afterwards, it's probably a good idea to warm up your vocal chords. Pool table is a bonus, and an easy place to start conversations. Don't try to bum any ciggies outside though, some girls only do it in exchange for jokes.
author: Van X.

description:
I usually don't go out in this area but Bloodhound is a gem of San Francisco happy hour hunters and drink enthusiasts. When you step into Bloodhound you immediately feel hip. This is San Francisco drinking at its core. There are dive bars, and eclectic places like Kozy Kar but like it or not this is what SF is becoming. Trendy and ironic and tech people with a ton of excess money to spend. 

We came for a pop up dinner event so it was extra crowded but even after the even closed up the place got more crowded. There were a lot of people with backpacks loaded with clothes and computers coming from work in the area. A lot of work meetups and happy hours as well as some first dates and social gatherings. It was super busy but kind of comforting to be around a ton of 25-40 year olds who had their own things going on and were actually really nice. 

The bar is super clean and the aesthetic is undefinable which I have kind of gotten used to in SF. Its like local edition but not underground which is a great thing actually. The lighting is really hazy here but its great to be able to step outside if you want to. The bartenders were relatively nice despite being incredibly busy. They also have a great selection of cocktails. Really that's what it comes down to with bars like this. There are a ton of them in SF so what do they have to keep you coming back? 

Location, the crowd, and the drinks are usually what get you. Bloodhound has all of this and its evident by how many people are there at all times that they are doing something right. Ultimately if you are cool with drinking around a ton of loud and enthusiastic working adults and sipping on obscure drinks in mason jars then you are going to love this place. 

If any of that sounds awful then you should find another place. In a world of tattoos, mustaches, ginger infused drinks and odd things hanging from the walls this place is going to satisfy but its also going to feel just like every one of the 50 other bars that do it as well.
author: Nick R.

description: Good neighborhood spot to visit.  Plenty of space, not too crowded, good cocktails, and games to entertain.  Also, there are black birds painted on the ceiling
author: Charles C.

description: Stopped in to Bloodhound Saturday night when we were early for our dinner reservation at Rocco's.  Very cool neighborhood bar.  A cool, vibey joint with a jukebox, pool table, a very impressive selection of spirits, and beers.  The Owner/Bartender is very good at what he does.  He and another Bartender were both very nice, and Mixed us a couple of rounds of very tasty Mexican Mules.  We would definitely go back to this great SOMA find!!
author: Christine Z.

description:
Went to this bar with some friends and was overall pretty happy with the atmosphere, the bartenders, and the crowd.

It was full, but not overly daunting to get around. I think it was a good size crowd.

The atmosphere is a mix of different things, but mostly what I would call rustic. There is an animal skull on the wall and barrels around the area to use as tables. They have a single pool table within the back of the bar, which gains a lot of popularity and use all throughout the night.

All of their bartenders were very nice and friendly except for one. I had been drinking for a few hours at this point and went up to the bar to get a water. When I got back to my friends we all ended up sharing it. I went back up about 5 minutes later, same bartender, and asked for another water. His response was, "I thought I already gave you one." I explained that I gave it to my friends and he followed up with a very rude, "Next time how about you ask for two, so we don't have to go through this."

Overall, the Bloodhound was a very positive experience and I enjoyed my evening there. I would recommend it to friends.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Unpretentious, below where I stayed and has a pool table.

If  I stay close again in the future, nice place to just hang out and chill with friends.

decor is interesting with window views of sidewalk people.  Since this is in Folsom this can be interesting in some nights.
author: Melanio F.

description:
If you either didn't make it inside Raven Bar or had the honor of being escorted out with your tiara on one hand, corona on the other,  Bloodhound is luckily right next door.  

A well decorated and curated bar with a gorgeous whiskey display complete with regulars  from the SF ad agency cool kids club.  Bloodhound also has a pool table and Deer Hunter Arcade machine (eats up your dollars).
Overall,  Bloodhound is a chill place to hang out and get a few drinks in on a Friday night.  

Now, I was pretty amazed by this place's Old Fashioned since the ONLY place I know that somewhat perfected it is Sip Bar on North Beach.   

So to sum it up

- Try their Old Fashioned. A must
- While you're at it, also check out their Moscow Mule!
author: Geo D.

description:
Another one of my favorite bars in the city, Bloodhound is another quality establishment for Prohibition-style drinks, styled much in the way of a traditional hunters' lodge. Big Game Hunter in one corner, mounted deer/moose head in the back, pool table, and crowds of hipsters all amplify this effect greatly, for better or for worse. The only thing that ends up feeling a little out of place are the nice sectional couches that line the windows towards the front, but they're comfortable enough that I can't really complain, especially given the lack of low, accessible seating otherwise.

The majority of their drinks are served up in mason jars of varying sizes, which is kind of kitschy, but neat nonetheless. And with most priced at under $10, they're right around the same price point as equally enjoyable Rickhouse. Having tried the Recoil (Bulleit bourbon, St Germaine, lime, and ginger beer) and New Fashioned, I can highly recommend both - and the rest of their drinks are probably pretty good bets too.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - With a very spacious interior, people shouldn't encounter any problems getting in or around the lounge. The bar is, of course, standard bar height, but the end furthest from the entrance is actually standard table height, should you need to garner a bartender's attention.

Bathroom - Semi-private men's bathroom. I say semi-private because it's a single room with two urinals and a toilet, but there's no lock on the door, so... use at your discretion, or have a friend stand watch outside. Otherwise accessible, though those with wider wheelchairs may have trouble getting inside due to the side privacy panel of the urinal closest to the door.
author: Johnny W.

description:
This is one cool bar.  Probably too cool for someone like me.  Very dark atmosphere, wood paneled walls, & lots of good looking folks sipping drinks out of mason jars.

We were on our way to SO for some grub but had time for one more bar stop.  I had this place bookmarked for ages & I was excited to finally give it a try.

It was right before the holidays so I ordered a  hot buttered rum.  I really didn't know what was in a hot buttered rum but apparently it is hot water, butter, & rum.  (See?  I told you I wasn't cool enough for this bar.)  It was good & damn strong.  We would have stayed for drink #2 if our dinner destination didn't close so damned early.

I was surprised at how nice the surrounding neighborhood is...not sketchy at all.
author: Erin S.

description:
Have been here a few times now as it's right around corner from new office. On popular happy hour days like Thursdays and the noise is deafening and it's standing room only. 

However people tend to be friendly and make room to squeeze you in to their seating. Really solid well priced cocktails. 

Beer list looks ok, but I'll let my Beer Snob be the true judge of that.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Why does Bloodhound deserve 4-stars instead of 3?  Not because of their 1-toilet ladies restroom or the unusual 3-urinal compact men's restroom where anytime the door swings open, a bunch of dudes are whizzing uncomfortably in front of a long line of ladies waiting for their turn.  No...

Bloodhound gets 4 stars for their stiff drinks and killer bartenders!  How strong are their drinks?  For our crowd, we couldn't really enjoy it because all we tasted was alcohol but man, do you get your moneys worth of alcohol.  Came here for bday drinks and the bday girl didn't like her Spaghetti and meatballs drink (no, that's not the actual name but that's what I called it all night).  Bad-ass bartender, Rudy, was nice enough to make another drink for her but warned us not to get anything on the menu if we weren't looking for a bite.  The convo went something like this:

Me: I'm sorry, would you mind replacing this drink with something else?
Rudy: What was it?
Me: The spaghetti and meatballs
Rudy:....the WHAT?
Me: This one! *points to spaghetti and meatballs
Rudy: *SMH* What's wrong with it?
Me: It's too stiff!
Rudy: ...alright, what you want?
Me: uhm..,
Rudy: You didn't think of what you wanted?! -brb-
Me: I GOT IT! The Whiskey Apple Sour!
Rudy: *nods*
Me: THE WHISKEY APPLE SOUR@!!!@
Rudy: I HEARD YOU!!!
Me: No Spaghetti!!
Rudy: -_-

I love a bartender with a sense of humor and can handle obnoxious people like me.  It's a quality that all bartenders should have, in my opinion, because they carry the event!  The drinks they make and the kind of service they provide can really set the mood for the evening.  

It's hot as hell in this joint.  Why the fan on the wall wasn't turned on beats the crap out of me.  The crowd was a mix of hipsters, weirdos, and Santaconers.  By weirdos, I mean this conversation:

dude: Is this your local bar?
friend: No..
dude: oh, because you look really familiar?
friend: Oh.. heh *hesitant laugh*
dude: You really do!  I think I've seen you from somewhere!
me: You prob have cause she's a model
friend: No.. no I'm not
dude: Oh, yea you look like a model! Like a charlie's angel.  *points to me* You could be a charlie's angel, too
me: What, because you think I look like Lucy Liu and all Asians look alike?
dude: .... 
me: I'm just messin with you
dude: yeah.. cool *nods head..awkward silence*

I'd come back for beer.
author: Kat C.

description:
My first experience at Bloodhound a year ago was a positive one. My most recent one was so bad, I left in tears.

My friends and I were at Raven next door. One incredibly intoxicated friend disappeared from the bar and wasn't answering his phone. He is from out of town and doesn't know his way around the city. It was pouring rain. Figuring that he may have ducked into Bloodhound, I headed over there.

Now, I'm a pretty polite person. So I asked the bouncer, "Excuse me. I'm looking for a friend who is lost. Do you mind if I check if he's here?"

Bouncer: "No, we're closing." 

He then proceeded to violently push an intoxicated man out the door (no clue about the man's previous behavior or if the push was justified, but at the time the man hadn't done or said anything)---directly into a girl. Yes, he violently pushed someone into an innocent bystander. The girl was struck in the face and was very upset. The bouncer apologized to the girl, said "stay out!" to the guy, then turned to me and physically removed me from the door frame (didn't ask me to leave, just strong armed me out the door.)

Me: "Sorry, do you mind if I just scan the room? He is very drunk, from out of town. I'm just trying to find him."

Bouncer: "It's not my f****** fault you lost your f******  friend. That's your f****** fault. Now get out."

...............

Completely uncalled for. I was sober. I was polite. I wasn't disorderly. It wasn't after closing, but a few minutes before and my request to scan the room would have taken all of about 30 seconds. People were still seated, enjoying drinks. There was no reason for his atrocious behavior. I've since tried calling the bar to speak with a manager four times. Each time the phone rings and rings and never reaches a voicemail or a person on the other line.

Horribly unprofessional and I won't be back.
author: Marcella D.

description:
BUCK HUNTER. Nuff said.

No really though, this place is casual, makes stiff drinks and is just a fun place to get together with friends. Low fuss, high fun.
author: Liz T.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this bar. I can't say enough good things about it:)

The bartenders are super nice,  and they make killer drinks. The cocktails are creative and delicious. Some of the best I've had, and not overpriced either. There's also an impressive beer selection. (I'm not a beer drinker, but my husband is.)

Other patrons are friendly, and the overall vibe awesome.

I SO wish this place was in my 'hood, I'd be regular.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Correction: it's the Carter BEATS the Devil. My bad. 

The drink is served a little different since the last time I was there. It used to be over the rocks in a highball with a salt rim. Now they went all frou frou and serve it in a martini glass. Strange. The actual drink tastes the same, in case you were curious.
author: Abby S.

description:
I spent a good couple hours in this drinking establishment playing pool and enjoying a few beers. This should be an item on everyone's bar-hopping list.

The highlight of my experience here was this. When I was getting ready to hop to the next bar, this Asian guy outside named Petey said something along the lines of, "you guys can't leave, we're going to take a shot right now." We all walked back into the bar, he threw down his jacket, and began to barback to earn 6 shots of tequila. Apparently he works with the bartender at another bar and he was helping him run the show for a little bit to get the shots for free. We found a table while he was doing his thing and 10 minutes later Petey brought us 6 shots on the house--made possible by his hard work of picking up glasses and stocking shelves. We hung around for another 30 minutes talking about the rigors of life and New Years Eve. This was a moment where a nice person did a nice thing. This man deserves a good break in life.

At any rate, this is probably now one of my favorite dive bars to hang around in SOMA. That night, we ate at The Chieftain Irish Pub, went to the Tempest Bar (another awesome dive bar), then spent most of the night at Bloodhound. This was a fun battle plan that night. I thought about the Bloodhound Gang (band) when my friend was initially telling me about this place.
author: Marlon T.

description: Crowded! But what can you expect for a friday night haha. Beer and a shot special was awesome for our group for $8 can't go wrong! very clean environment and pool table was a nice touch.
author: K M.

description:
Bloodhound is a cool bar with a nice vibe. I was there last Saturday night with a few of my buddies and it was filled with a pretty mixed crowd. You get everyone from hipsters to wannabe Hollywood types, hippies, nerds, geeks, preppies, etc. I love going to place with a diverse crowd because I enjoy people watching and, well, I just love people! I'm kind of chatter box around strangers. Yeah, I'm that guy who walks up to everyone and strikes up a conversation. 

The decor is pretty cool. It has, what I call, a hipster gothy cabin look to it. Really dim with hanging antler chandeliers, a long bar that looks like it's made out of old barn wood, a ton of communal tables and a pool table in the back. The bartenders are cool and they pour their drinks pretty heavy, which is something I appreciate - anything to get me closer to blacking out. 

Overall, I'm a fan of Bloodhound. It's mellow but has an upbeat vibe at the same time. It's a great place to grab a drink with a big group of friends.
author: Bruce C.

description:
Nor me or girlfriend got in.  I didn't bring my passport and had only my non-american I.D so we couldn't get in.  That's cool, I get the point -it was our fault after all for not bringing it.  But my negative review is based on the following exchange of words with the bouncer:

After he saw my foreign ID and rejected it asked me for my passport:
Me:  Sorry man, I didn't want to bring my passport to a bar. 
B: WELL, YOU ARE SUPPOSED TO (yes, with that army treatment)
Me: Maybe, but I didn't want to risk it, that's cool.  We won't get in.
B: OK THEN KEEP WALKING. (He stood up and basically, kicked us out of the sidewalk)
Me:  Alright, but you are not having the most polite attitude either man.
B: F*CK YOU!!  (yes, he screamed that to me and my girlfriend)
Me: ....wow
B: GET THE F*CK OUT.  And he raised his middle finger to us.

Of course, I  was not going to fight it or exchange words with that gorilla.  He would've kicked my ass anyways and make Folsom a real bloodhound.

Don't know anything about the bar menu or decor or anything.  Maybe it's the best one in SF, but it was a wednesday, 9pm.  e were sober, just walking by, and there were probably 50 people inside  and no one else on the line.  What was the need to insult us?
Don't know who is this guy used to deal with, but certainly that was not us.  It was shocking.  We will not get back to this place again.
author: Bruno W.

description:
This is a cool spot! We almost missed it because the sign is hard to read and there's a club next door with a line out the door that can lead you to think the stuff around it is closed, but alas, it's worth looking for. 

We came later in the evening and the bar was pretty dark and loud inside. It's not dancey or club like at all, though -- the vibe is hipster meets western. There are antlers, crows, unfinished wood, etc. but the crowd is your typical SF tech/grunge look and there seemed to be a lot more men than women there (no complaints from me and my girlfriends -- we're all spoken for, but that's beside the point). 

Despite the crowded space, it was easy to get served and the drinks we ordered all packed a punch in terms of flavor and strength. I'm terrible at remembering what my drinks are called, but the one I had here was apple-y and full of spice. 

As far as people watching went, we had some good entertainment. A couple making out in a corner for longer than any high schooler I've ever seen, some bizarre pool table interactions, and then a girl who was fondling my hair while her boyfriend struggled to gather their coats from the coat hooks. 

In any case -- seemed like everyone was having a good night! I'd come back.
author: Lauren J.

description:
One star vote only for the décor and the nice bearded bartender that night.

I went the night of March 4th, Tuesday for my friends B-Day....

The Music was SO loud I had to scream at my friend who was sitting right next to me. So imagine trying to order a drink....

The other bartender that night pist me off.  He was so rude and ignored me every time I tried to order.  He'd come up to get the order and then walk away before I was finished talking.  One instance I started to order with him and in the middle of me ordering he turns to look at my friend besides me and takes her order and completely ignores me.  My friend noticed and included my drink in her order to make sure I'd get mine.   

After reading some of the reviews on this bar I noticed a trend...

Hey, Bloodhound owners! Are you going to do something about your di*k head bartender or what?
author: Raquel G.

description:
Oh the bad bartender. The one the looks at you, then turns and walks away. This happens once at a bar and you ignore it. Happens a second time and you say something. Happens a 3rd time and you have your final drink there.
You use to be soo good bloodhound. Then you got cocky and started acting as toranado and serving drinks like a dive.  
So long.
author: Tim K.

description:
Selection is medium-to-extensive, and powerful
Vibe is tight
Music is great

I made my way here on a Tuesday night not long ago and made a pretty full night of it - an outstanding choice, if I do say so myself.  As I first walked in, Amanda offered assistance and we immediately got into a fine chat about the region's beers, the immediate local neighborhood, and some East Coast musings, as well.  She was generous with the samples and spot-on with her recommendations - a pleasure to speak with.  Later on, her compadre Rudy (who invents cocktails) came in and mixed up a Smoky Old-Fashioned for me, which was most excellent.  

Everyone else is right about the dark atmosphere and hunting lodge-chic.  Expect it, revel in it, and that's that - it's cool and not overdone.  On this specific night, the darkness was actually broken up by a Presidential motorcade hustling through town that bathed Folsom in red and blue flashes for about ten minutes as the advance team blocked entry and exit, and our Homebrewer-In-Chief sped past.  We, the fair patron citizenry spilled out onto the sidewalk for a look-see (and some for a smoke).  Then, as that broke up, we all returned inside the bar to polish off our beverages.  

This place is great.  I try to do new things every time I visit San Francisco, but I have a feeling I'll have a hankering to make this a repeat stop in future.  Love it.
author: Ben S.

description: Straight-shooting bartenders. Couches to sit on. Decent drinks.
author: Inigo M.

description:
We live around the corner from this place and have been visiting there once in a while for some time. The service has plummeted since it first opened. The bartenders there are really rude. The guy with the beard and glasses and a red beanie, should be fired. I don't know what he's doing there, when he can't handle the stress of a lot of people wanting drinks.

Tonight we visited, and it was my one night off in a long time. After opening a tab and grabbing one drink, I wanted another one. After waiting for 30 min I waived at the bar tender and in response I got "Hold on! Wait! Fuck!" His response shocked me and really almost brought me to tears. All I wanted was to spend a night having fun and he ruined it for me. Never going back there again and I urge the management to turn things around. If he was having a bad night he should not have been working. He insulted me so bad that I signed up for Yelp just to write this. Blood hound is a great place, but they really need to be careful who they choose to work there. Never going back again!!!!
author: Elena S.

description:
Awesome place. Strong cocktails, drinks served in mason jars, dogs welcome, a pool table, dark hardwood, and big buck hunter. What is not to like?

Pretty chill during the week and starts to get busy friday and saturday around 11pm.

Great place to start the night!
author: Andy J.

description:
I live across the street and have been here literally a milion times. Yes literally. This is a really great place to have a drink and just chill. The signature drinks are very good but a bit pricey for how little alcohol they have in them. There is a pool table and a couple arcade games. The floor is rather spacious but nothing too big. Security is always super chill and never looking to kick someone out for no reason.

There are a couple couches in the front so there is seating but it's almost always taken. If you're looking to grab a drink and be able to hear and converse with your friends then this is a great place. There is no dance floor but if you want to dance go next door to Raven.
author: William L.

description:
Adorable concept. I felt like I'd been transported to a cabin in the woods (which of course couldn't be further from Soma, SF). 

It's a hunter's haven, with an antler chandelier, animal skulls adorning the walls, blackbird decals on the ceiling, rustic wood tables and stools, and an ARCADE HUNTING GAME in the corner. (Some guy paid extra money and let my friends and I take it over. Thank you, sir! So fun to play when you're tipsy. Also, impossible to beat.)

A bartender who looked about 18 years old mixed me up a phenomenal gin martini. Impressive.

Expertly mixed drinks, fun decor and a packed bar at 7pm on a Friday evening = my new favorite spot in Soma!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Follow the scent.

To extremely well priced drinks. Can't remember the last time I paid $6 for a vodka soda. Oh yes I do. Here.

To a lively and unique scene. Mason jars. Pool tables. Birds on the ceiling. Antlers for chandeliers. Wood accents and vintage lighting. Loud and contagious conversation. Here.

If done right your next night out will lead to one of the best bars in the city. Here.
author: Jason B.

description: Really enjoy this laid back feel to the bar.  Came here after the line at Raven Bar was too crowded.  I was glad we made it to this place.  There is usually a good amount of people without it being overwhelming.  They have one long bar with enough bar tenders to keep the lines short or none at all.  They serve their beer in mason jars and the prices are not too bad.  In the middle is a pool table and they also have the duck hunter shooting game.
author: Justin Y.

description:
So we decided to come here because we were tired of dancing and wanted to sit, relax, have a drink, and just chat.  

The decor is nice.  I think that that was the best part of this place.

The bartenders were so sarcastic to the point of being absolutely rude.  We had a really large group so we were deciding on what to drink, and they started pouring when we were still unsure of the number and charged us even though they poured us more than what we had wanted.  And they originally said they couldn't make the drink for us, but did anyways.  

This place is lucky I even gave it 1 star, and that's for the decor.

Beware of bad bartenders, IF you decide to go here.
author: Liliana P.

description:
Nice atmosphere, love the lighting, quirky bird silhouette pattern, and antler chandelier. 


12.24.13
author: Angela L.

description:
Bloodhound is my kind of bar. The decor is cool and dark, there are leather sofa chairs and couches, saw a couple of shooting games, a pool table, and strong drinks.  I even liked the dark western vibe they had going on with their mounted cow skull and antler chandelier. The bartender knew what he was doing and made an amazing manhattan.  It did a few of us in pretty good for just one drink.  I liked their own creations in mason jars as well.

I arrived right around 6pm and was able to find parking right in front. It was early enough to grab a section of the couch to lounge and before the real post work crowd swarmed in.
author: Samantha L.

description:
If there's any bar in SF that makes me feel like I'm hanging out in good 'ol Portland, Oregon, it's Bloodhound. Why? 

1. Beards and beanies. They're everywhere. Plaid shirts, beards and beanies. I felt like I stepped out of a Pendleton Woolen Mills commercial and onto the lumberjack-chic streets of PDX. 

2. Hunting lodge decór. I have been asking around for years and still have yet to determine what made hip people decide that a hunting lodge theme complete with taxidermy animals, hunting cammo and antlers is... well... hip. Is it the city-dweller's only connection with the natural world? Maybe. Were these kids all raised by hicks that hunt for fun? No. But I see it everywhere in Portland. If anyone can answer this one for me, please end my years-long confusion.

3. Laid back vibe. This is something that just doesn't seem to exist in many SF bars. Why? Because SF is not a laid back city.  Sorry, it's just not. 

4. Good beer on tap. Not the best tap selection in the world, mind you, but good enough.

5. Buck Hunter. No, I'm not going to claim that Buck Hunter is a Portland thing... it's a hipster thing. But Portland is disproportionately full of hipsters, so many of which are vegetarian. I cannot for the life of me understand why this game is so popular. I've tried playing it a couple of times and... well... I am just not in to killing animals for sport. Also see #2 above. 

6. Beards and... wait, did I already mention this one? 

Seriously, I walked in here to meet with some folks, and I was the first to arrive. As I sat there drinking my brew I surveyed the scene and determined that I could just as easily be at a bar in Portland instead of SF. And that's definitely worth 4-stars to me.
author: Don B.

description:
I'm really  mad that I hadn't visited Bloodhound sooner! I'm always in the area yet never heard of this great bar until last night. As soon as I walked in I felt comfortable - no scene, no pretension (though there is some noticeable antler decor). 

I perused their cocktail menu but decided to go with the Greyhound, as I'm not a huge fan of Campari or of Bourbon, and there seemed to be a lot of both of those on their specialty drinks. It may have been one of the best greyhounds that I've ever had, and it was also the place where I learned of the Salted Dog, which is a greyhound with a salted rim. Yum!

The bar itself is super laid back and comfortable, with some big leathery couches that we all sprawled out on as well as some fun rolling office type chairs. The only reason I'm not giving it a full five stars (though my experience was pretty darn close) was that I really felt like I'd seen this concept before and it wasn't necessarily the most unique decor or ambiance. But hey, it works!
author: Christina P.

description:
Drinks are good, but bartenders can be rude.

Not too crowded on a weekday night, and a pool table and arcade game in the back.
author: Vivian H.

description:
A huge group of us ended up at Bloodhound on a Tuesday evening and the bar did not disappoint. After getting an intoxicating whiff of a whiskey-based drink, I had to order one for myself. The New Fashioned may well become my next signature cocktail. Made with honey instead of sugar, it was a cool spin off from an original Old Fashioned (no muddling), with a soothing taste. 

The long bar offered ample room for ordering, and lounge-style and table seating made for a chill atmosphere. The lights were appropriately dim, providing gentlemen with the added courage to strike up flirtatious banter. 

The juke box was appropriately filled with classics, although the volume was low until the wee hours of the night. I look forward to returning on my next trip to San Francisco!

Bonus tip: Check out the kitschy website complete with a fun soundtrack!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Saturday night was busy with a friendly mix of people. Toucan, Amanda and Steven are some of the nicest, friendliest, downright best bar staff you're ever likely to encounter. Even though amanda did screw us with some tequila shots! 

Just about quiet enough to have a chat, loud enough so no one else can here it. 

All in all, a great bar.
author: Richard M.

description: This is a great spot Dwtn and actually walking distance from me. I love that it's not overly crowded and the atmosphere is really fun. It has a pretty eclectic crowd and it's a good place to meet up or just keep your night there. The drinks are pretty tasty!
author: Priya S.

description: Good divey bar in civic center. Drinks are solid and well made and not too pricey. They make a great old fashioned. As others have mentioned it's quite dark and has a casual ambience. Overall a solid bar but I prefer Oddjob which is just a few blocks walk away.
author: Michael L.

description:
My guy and I arrived here after going to some beer snobby hipster place across the street where you have to sit on cold beer kegs.. Anyhow, we finished the Centennial 12K of Bay to Breakers and it was turning into a lazy Sunday afternoon. We wandered in and pulled up to the bar. Keep in mind this is on a Sunday and we were leaving Monday afternoon to come back to San Diego.. So it was a nice comfy Sunday afternoon where most of the City's actual residents were passed out or playing basketball in costumes (like Catholic School girl costumes on a bunch of boise) in the park

I like this place for a host reasons, super friendly locals with dogs who would wander over to talk to us. Loads of TV's since I am a sports fan...I was practically orgasmic and great beers on tap. It's got a "hunting vibe and decor" to it which I am sure comes in quite handy after several grey hounds on a Saturday night.  Quite a few moody hipsters lounging and working on their laptops.

Our bartender was great and like I said, so were the locals. My husband and I had several pints purchased for us for finishing Bay to Breakers. Great place to spend a Sunday afternoon, sort of reminds me of the Whistle Stop in my 'hood.  If I were a local in SF, I can tell you that I would most definitely be found here with my dog on any given weekend daytime.
author: Patricia Patti P W.

description:
Bloodhound is one of my favorite spots in SF, because it provides everything I love in a good bar:

Excellent people-watching. Bloodhound attracts a unique assortment of people (it can't lure in too many of any specific type because of the location). A perfect platform for start-up tech nerds and beanied hipsters to collide and argue about their respective integrality to SF culture. 

Strong drinks, complimented by the beautiful wood-paneled antler-clad interior. And, most importantly, lovely warm lighting: you look good at this bar. 

Guys with beards in flannel. Full disclosure, I have a highly sensitive radar for this. 

It's essentially an urban cabin, which is my best-of-both-worlds ideal. Not a place to get wild, but definitely a fun place to grab a couple of drinks on a Saturday night.
author: Meredith C.

description:
Evil is what you make it. I'm certain Bloodhound is the devil in disguise. 

Both times I've stopped in for a drink, I leave totally wasted and satisfied. The bartenders are really friendly and answer all my annoying questions. Drinks are very strong and tasty. 

I would recommend the Recoil, New Fashioned and the Gimlet.  Tuesday's are great  because it's slow but Thursday's are great too, even though it's packed.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Straight chill. Second only to Burritt Room, the wee hunter's hidey-hole that could poured the best fashioned Old Fashioned this week. And you can trust me; I quaffed quite the scale.

With a well hung bevvy of zootopia past, the collection is just shy of Buckshot's breadth yet suckers me in with chanteliers and a surrounding darkness that incepts the ultimate PETA nightmare: moving mounts and shifting lines of sight that track every sip of your Mason jar beverage.

It's like mother/pet guilt all at once. Uncomfortable? No. Increasingly disconcerting as you pound drinks? Maybe.

Doesn't need a lot to ride this wave of effortless cool, so the pool table and funky j-box spread icing on the cake. It's a guaranteed stop in the SF rotation.
author: Damien S.

description:
I only thought this place was ok, but I know a lot of other people who would really really enjoy it!

CROWD: My friends and I were a bit over dressed because we wanted to go to a club.  Our only friend who actually lived in SF told us that she came here a lot to "pregame" for clubs, which is why we came here looking ridiculous.  I didn't care that much.  I like dressing up!  It was kind of annoying to have people give dirty looks though.  Sorry I left my plaid shirt at home?  The people here definitely were not yuppies, but they had to know that they were kind of paying a lot for what they were getting?  Just seemed like a bunch of hipsters who thought they were cool for being at an alternative bar that's not a full on sports bar or whatever.  I'll explain more later.

AMBIANCE: Anyway, that was not a big deal.  This place had a cool ambiance.  Although it looks like it would be a manly masculine amurrican place to be with the log cabinesque decorations / antlers / stone ipa on tap, it really was... not anything like that at all.  In fact, this place reminded me of Urban Outfitters.  There were black birds painted on the ceiling, antlers for chandelier lights... all very "urban".  Very hip.

Still, if you didn't know any better about retail / interior design, you'd probably be easily fooled into thinking that this place was a real manly place.  My boyfriend and his friends would have probably thought this place was sooo cooool.

SERVICE: Awesome!  Very fast... the bartender was actually nice to us, unlike most of the other people at the bar.  A lot of old guys came and teased us because we seemed out of place.  Whatever.  Anyway, even though the place was PACKED, the bartender could pretty easily pick out who hadn't ordered yet.  They seemed to have a pretty efficient system going on there!

Would I come back here again?  Probably!  Probably with some friends.  To people watch.  To people watch the "hipsters" who think they're so "alternative" by going to a bar like this, but are actually paying just as much as they would at another loungey-er bar.
