If you're not a cocktail person (gasp), they also tend to have pretty decent beer on tap as well, and a pretty good selection of higher-end whiskey (& some other stuff) for sipping on.

Cocktails run the SF standard $9-10 each. I do like that there is some non-bar seating (a few vinyl couches & tables scattered around the far side of the bar), and I've always had great service. My only beef is the noise level -- the place can get REALLY loud if it's at all crowded, to the point where you sometimes have to yell so that the person ten inches away can hear you. Try it on an off night or go early if you can.
author: Angela B.

description:
I was pretty skeptical about this place when I first walked in. I was meeting some colleagues for an after work happy hour and this place does not exactly strike me as a place professionals go after a long day of work. It is pretty dim lighting and has relatively limited seating with no waiter service. My rating is biased because I was not anticipating this type of setting based on what I was originally told. I would probably go back for a Friday or Saturday night and have a good time but not an after work place for me. 

One redeeming aspect of Bloodhound is the fact they offer Olympia beer. After spending four years in Seattle and enjoying Olympia thoroughly up there, it is refreshing to find some in SF.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This is where you want to go on a sunny afternoon or one of your chill nights out.  The Bloodhound is welcoming and stocked with a fantastic list of alcohol.  The beers (both on tap and bottled) are amazing!  I especially love the La Chouffe on tap!  Also, the bar is spacious and warm.  The only thing missing from this bar atmosphere is YOU!  Come and enjoy a great place for drinking. 

P.S. The have Buckhunter Pro - a bonus star in my BF's book.  Also, minus one star for the location:  I love the stuff of Folsom St. but I'm spoiled and I hate how everything is so spread out.
author: Lisa R.

description: This place is the best! Love coming here after school or work and unwinding. Couches and great seating, pool table, machine gun game. Yup it's good stuff
author: Netta W.

description:
Affectionately renamed "Blackout Bloodhound" 
I don't know what is in the bourbon here but whether I have 1 drink or 3 at bloodhound, I never seem to remember parts of the evening....

The bourbon galore and friendly attitude of the barstaff/owners drive this place to 4 stars and make it worth the trek. No matter how deep at the bar  I can always find a bartender looking out for me, they are always happy to refill my water and always friendly enough to suggest a budget bourbon if the night calls for it and they always pour stiff drinks. The Chairman truck on Wed with the pork belly buns are a must. 

I've been there on a Wed & a Sat, always starts out lightly populated and ends up jam packed. Crowd is super friendly, chatty and down to earth. No douche-bags in site - let's keep it that way.

One less star for horrendous acoustics, you have to yell in a whisper position to communicate after 10pm but by that point you won't know what is going on anyways...
author: AK S.

description:
I really wish this place wasn't so far from my house because I am newly obsessed! I'm from the South, so mason jars and Buck Hunter make me feel right at home. The drinks were knock you on your ass strong but still tasted great, and were very generously sized.

I went on a Wednesday, and the crowd was an impressive size and mix of types of people. I will definitely be back!
author: Megan S.

description:
So I was wrestling about the rating on this one. I really wanted to give it 5 stars but didn't want to become one of those false praisers that give McDonald's a 5 star rating. I want to be discerning. But after careful bullet-point consideration I can't think of a single thing I don't like about this bar.

Let's start with the most important thing about a bar, the drinks: They are good! They have a specialty drink list that is tasty and seems to be ever changing. I'm a whiskey guy and while their selection isn't the most extensive it has some quality hooch on board.

Prices: It is quite reasonable. I was there with a group of friends and it was something like $30 for 5 drinks. And that included one or two higher priced premium drinks.

Service: The really cool thing about this place is that the bartenders (some are the owners) are REALLY nice! I can't stand when I go to a bar, Ahem Pink Elephant San Diego, and the people who work there are just assholes! These guys and gals are awesome!

Ambiance: The crowd is definitely not the green as the valley 21 year olds that trash a place and puke outside. Classy people in their mid-late 20's all the way to late 30's but honestly diverse, mellow and polite. The taxidermy aesthetic is warm but original and lends itself to the hunters' lodges and workmen's bars of the Ozarks but with a pristine and fresh twist.

Food: They don't serve any but there is usually a food truck out front, pizza is close by and there is a newly anointed bacon-wrapped hotdog stand out front. PLUS!

love this place, it's our neighborhood bar. Love!
author: aaron c.

description:
Bloodhound is a solid bar in SOMA for sitting down with friends for a well-poured pint or cocktail.  The bar is shockingly clean, but avoids feeling sterile because of the wooden, country-ish decor.  Drawbacks are that the drinks are pricey, and that it's out of the way for where I live in Russian Hill.  Being that this is more of a "have a drink with the lads" joint, I feel like this bar would be better located in a place like Polk Street or Hayes Valley, but I guess SOMA needs a normal bar too.

The big bartender guy is really knowledgeable, but if you catch him at the wrong moment can be a little impatient and snappy.  Nonetheless, you will get what you order, and it will be well-poured.  I highly recommend the buttered rum for colder evenings!  It is truly delicious, and you can say that you've actually tried that noble and classic drink, The Buttered Rum.  It's kind of like drinking warm and tasty egg nog.

The door is always open here, in a literal sense, so dress warm (or enjoy them buttered rums).

Pool and other game machines toward the back where they belong, and the men's room is really clean.
author: Dmytro A.

description: Nice selection of beer and cocktails.  Loved that people brought their dogs into the bar.   The place has a nice open feel with a hunters lodge look.
author: Zed Z.

description: I just moved to SF and I'm happy to have Bloodhound as one of my local neighborhood bars.  Delicious drinks (try the Recoil -- ginger beer mmmmm), awesome ambiance and friendly bartenders. If you have a complicated drink order, they got it.   I also LOVE the fact that they have Buck Hunter; however, it's the HD super high-end version which actually makes it like 100 times harder than the original! Never thought I would complain about Buck Hunter being too high-end  :-D
author: Jessica R.

description:
Decent neighborhood bar with an eclectic crowd and pretty good beer menu. Pool table in the back that seems to get some decent use and the game "Buckshot". 

They don't serve food here, but they are completely fine with you bringing your own food in. The first time I came here someone totally saved the day with loaded cheese fries. Was that you Seong? Or maybe Luis? On my recent visit here there was a guy making gourmet pizzas outside with just a little grill and a pizza stone. Pretty awesome. There was also a Chez Spencer food truck parking in the parking lot of the oil change place on the corner.
author: Jen D.

description: Excellent cocktails.. try an off the menu favorite of mine... oaxaca old fashioned (mezcal)
author: Ali H.

description:
A really cute SoMa bar with fun decor and mason jars for drinks. A little on the price-y side for some of their specialty cocktails, but definitely a perfect places for a drink after work or a laid-back night.

The greyhound-like drink was good, but a little too sweet, bitter. Would prefer less juice.
author: christine c.

description: Bloodhound. More people in black thick glasses than I can count. I came here for a beer tasting event and it was packed like sardines.  The event itself gets 5 stars but this is a review for Bloodhound. First thing I noticed were the black birds across the ceiling. Then the black glasses. Then the oddly large amount of hipsterly dressed people.  I have nothing against hipster; just noticing. Maybe I should have known when IPA was on tab. Most of the stars go to the friendly male bartender who gave my friend and I a free beer. I wish the venue had more seats and it would be nice to have a dimmer setting. I didn't venture far enough to check out the bathroom. Was in and out in an hour.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Perfectly chill/non-pretentious/laid back place to grab some happy hour lovin' ... And by lovin' I mean quality cocktails, good friends, cool vibe and an overall good time. Well, not "good time" ... but good time. Oh sheesh.  Whatever.

Order the Recoil (some potent killer mix of Bourbon, Elderflower, lime and some other goodness served up in a mason jar), shoot some pool and have a happy hour.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description: 5 stars for easy parking, potent drinks, fun-hipster watching, excellent outdoor grill pizza and a super cool bouncer!
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Great vibe. Good drinks. A little on the pricey side...

I'll write a more thorough review when I go here first, rather than last.
author: Dalton C.

description:
Bloodhound has really grown on me.  It's surprising to me when people call this a dive bar.  It's far from it.

1) Dive bars are dirty nasty places -- this place is nice, not fancy or anything, but has some cool decorations (take a look at the ceiling).  You probably don't need a tetanus shot before coming here or anything.
2) They serve more than just beer and booze straight up.  In fact, they have a great selection of alcohol.
3) They serve mixed drinks.  Their signature (and my favorite) is the Recoil. Their drinks are served in cool mason jars.
4) They have a drink menu...
5) They have a bouncer that checks ID.  They have "standards" here.  Oh, maybe that's a San Francisco thing.
6) Their drinks cost more than $2-5. 

Anyways, it's quickly become a staple when I think of going to the city for a drink.  I could go for a recoil right now.  It can get pretty crowded, but still a great choice for a group.
author: Van W.

description: In SF visiting for the weekend and fell I love with this bar. I want to move it to my hometown. Every bartender was great. The service was perfect and the drinks didn't skimp. I also loved how dog friendly they were. Wish I could have met Floyd the Great Dane. I heard so much about him.
author: Erin T.

description:
This ended up being a really great spot to meet some folks at on a Friday evening. 

I tried to call them but no one ever picked up so I emailed to ask about reserving a table and someone responded super quickly.  I wanted to reserve a table area at 5:30pm and they were happy to do so. They have a bunch of long tables where you can sit. 

Good cocktails and some coming in the jars! 

They also have a shooting game where you have to put four quarters that seemed fun. 

Powell BART around the corner from this place (which is sketchy to walk to especially on 7th) and Specer's On The Go French Food drunk nearby. 

No food at Bloodhound but I ordered pizza from Extreme Pizza and they delivered and we enjoyed there. Glad they accept outside food. 

Would go again for sure.
author: Anya R.

description:
Bloodhound has become hands down my favorite bar in the city (and competition is stiff). A friend once asked why, and it's just because it flows at the right pace. Aside from the fact that they make great drinks, there's a certain je ne sais quoi about it. It's a chill bar without being divey. It's cool without being too trendy. There's a great mixed crowd so that you can't say it's a hipster bar, or a yuppie bar, or any other "insert stereotype here" bar. There's a pool table and a juke box, and dogs are allowed! Great food options nearby including the newly-discovered Chez Spencer food truck. (Yes, I only JUST discovered this almost a year later because I always make a direct beeline to Bloodhound.) And I always find parking nearby. 

It's so awesome I have dragged many friends and introduced them to Bloodhound and they, too, love it here. I'm slightly shocked that the bartenders don't know me by name, or at the very least, don't immediately start mixing a Recoil when they see me walk in the door. All in due time...
author: Leilani H.

description: I remember this place as Cassidy's, and boy the interior decorator really did a fantastic job sprucing this place up! Bartender's are super nice and jolly, not snobby hips. Mixed crowd. Props on the Old Speckled Hen. Mason jars are too sloppy.  Drinks were strong. I left perved. supa perved. A bit out of my usual way, but was not the hipster bar I thought it would be.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
The bar was ok. Just ok. I was in a group of 6 and we came to the bar around 2100 and the place had no seats. When I went to order a beer I dont remember them having any on tab. The Drink menu they had  like 5 things on it... 

But the price for drinks where ok... ooo yea they have one pool table in the back.
author: Jo M.

description: This place is my local stomping ground. My favorite bar in the area. Before they gutted the interior and re did the whole place, it pretty much sucked. Now however, it's awesome. Great alcohol selection, reasonable prices. Staff is hella friendly. They've got a pool table and some legit arcade games. Also has a juke box which is always a plus. The crowd is highly diverse. You've got your blazin hot marina type girls that get all decked out. And you've also got your tattooed and pierced hipster chicks rocking a bad haircut and hoodies. Either way, everyone gets along, and creates a super chill vibe that pretty much everyone can dig. Highly recommended.
author: Brett G.

description:
Awesome place with very friendly bartenders.

I had a party there last night and everything was just right. I would highly recommend to others to have a party at Bloodhound. I really like what was done with the place. The bar use to be called cassisdys, but with the new face lift Bloodhound is the place to go.

Beer was reasonable and good selection.
author: Dean C.

description: This bar is a great spot to meet friends. The cocktails are delicious, the service reasonably quick and friendly, the atmosphere stylish and chill,  and my mut, Lola, is welcome. I'm sold.
author: Mishka L.

description: Just met two new young architects. Hope to see them in the future!
author: CC K.

description:
Neat space full of friendly startup/tech types :)  The drinks are good, they have decent beer and scotch selection and best of all bartenders are friendly and you can get their attention quickly unlike most places where they try to avoid eye contact.  And this even though the place was packed.  So other bars, you have no excuse.  

Mason jars are a good idea too so you dont waste/slosh your drink all over the floor.  This way you are getting your money's worth.  

Birds on the ceiling make for interesting drunken pix of your friends too.

Their website has some cute game too but i havent played it.
author: X X.

description: Chill ass chick bartender! We got our drinks for hella cheap and big portions! I mean she filled it to the top! But some guy took off with our beer! But the bartender gave the guy a hard time about it! LOL!
author: Xuan C.

description:
I kinda like this place. The drinks are pretty good, but it gets crazy packed in here for a bar with no real dancing. I guess that's 'meh.' It's stumbling distance from my place, and the people who work here are pretty nice. 
Neighborhood joint to chill with the neighbors: Ok. I'll come back, but not always my first choice (eep! - sorry!)
author: Emdeezy F.

description:
This place generates a lot of hype. I'm not sure what all the critical talk is for, but if you're hating on the crowd who seems to make their way from all over the city to enjoy this spot, then stop being selfish and enjoy the fresh faces in SOMA. The hipsters can have all the other lousy bars around the area, or suck it up and share a little. 

Now that I got that off my chest... Bloodhound is a good spot. I really like the atmosphere. There is something very comforting about a lodge type place with tables made of trees, mason jars for beer mugs, and antlers hanging from the wall. The place is unique for the city, which is why people make their way even from the marina to enjoy it. 

I also thought the drinks were decently priced. I paid $13 for a mandarin soda and a bacardi and diet. Average in my book. Service was also quite good. I didn't have to wait long for a drink or to close out my tab, which is always a good thing (there are not many things I hate more than trying to get drunk at a bar and not being able to because you have to wait 20 minutes to order a drink!). So cheers bloodhound, I'll be back.
author: Krista S.

description: Only been here twice but I love the feel of this bar. Came for beers after a Superbowl Party and then another time for cocktails before heading to a show. This place has the same owners at Churchills and they stock the Chicharones that you see behind many of the bars in the city. A lot of space and a great central location to meet up after a long day or before a long night.
author: Anna R.

description:
I visit this watering hole every week with a group of my friends, and I must say, it's one of my favorite places in the city to hang.  

The service:  Great.  Friendly bartenders (some of them are the owners), they remember your name, and the conversation is pleasant when they aren't that busy.

The crowd: The 9-5ers, techies, artists and other pleasant company.  There are no trashy 20somethings or obnoxious over the top gays, hipsters or yuppies. (If they show up, they're very far and few.)  It's a nice mix of folks.  

The drinks:  Amazing beer selection served in mason jars.  Cocktails, from what I hear, are really good.  All are reasonably priced.  

Food:  None in the bar.  BUT, you can bring food in from local establishments or from the number of pizza, taco, or hot bun trucks parked outside.  

Bloodhound used to be less crowded than it is now, but the volume of people doesn't bother me so much since this place is deserving of a packed house.
author: Dudley F.

description:
Ladies, Bloodhound is the place to be for Happy Hour if you're on the prowl for a sexy man.  I arrived around 530/6pm and the place was bustling with hot men coming from work for a good straight hour! After that though, it cleared out and became more of a night scene.  

The drinks are sweet and the bartenders are sexy, in a cute hipster style way.  I had two bloodhounds, which are made with Hangar 1 vodka, campari, and grapefruit juice and one peach cobber (?? - I think that's what it's called), that was OK, but way too sweet for my liking.

There's not a hint of an attitude in the place - everyone is very friendly and I love all the wood detail and sofas at the front of venue.  I especially loved all the doves painted onto the eye-catching ceiling! So cute.  Definitely a great spot for a birthday party, date, happy hour, etc!
author: Jenny W.

description: I went here after work with a coworker a few weeks back just for a chill drink.  It wasn't too crowded or rowdy.  Music was a little loud but we were still able to make conversation! the bar tender was nice and the drinks were strong enough and still tasty.  I really need to start writing down the name of my drinks but.... I forgot and will probably have to update for the next time I come around.  Parking wasn't too hard to find at night but it's street like any other SF area!
author: Lisa L.

description:
This place was awesome.  It's a totally chill place to enjoy cocktails (and some beers) in a very nicely designed environment.

They have a great list of house cocktails: Probably about 15, which aren't all listed on their web site.  I forget the one we liked the most, but it was a bourbon + cointreau kinda thing, served up.  The bartenders were also knowledgable about call drinks -- we always order some Vieux Carres, and they came up fast and perfect.  Prices weren't bad either!

Highly recommended for dates & chill evenings with friends.
author: Jon E.

description: I was only here for about an hour but it was a cool vibe. Something about it reminded me a bit of Rickhouse but less pretentious. Laid-back, rustic setting and fun people.
author: Lauren C.

description: Awesome vibe in this place... nothing fancy, but very "under the radar" and hip. There was a huge dog as I walked in too... and I love when bar's have something random to remember them by. I'll definitely be back... I work only 2 blocks down so this could get dangerously fun...
author: Courtney M.

description:
I love pretty close to hear, and this is definitely a great addition to the area.

With some pretty solid spots around, such as city beer store, teroir, there needed to be a good bar with a solid punch. Bloodhound is exactly that.

The bar before Bloodhound here was 'Cassidy's'... good bar, but a totally different atmosphere and ambiance... Cassidy was more of a mild hole in the wall.

Bloodhound brings it up a couple of notches, and with it, attracts a crowd that's somewhat a splice marina and soma, but its not limited to that crowd only.. you get the locals in here as well... so its an interesting mix of people. Usually, a descent looking crowd in there... some nights get BUSY here. Esp the weekends, and I believe wed/thu can be busy here. Then again so can Tuesday, um, and Monday.

Plush settings, comfy couch, dim lighting, pool table, shooting game and good music... a bar with a lounge atmosphere and feel. The perfect go to bar in the area.

Also, a few days a week, there are food trucks, pizza ovens outside... I believe the Chariman Bao truck stops there on Wednesdays, and the pizza thing changed recently. Call them and ask. Great bar to grab food right outside, bring it in, chill on the sofa (if you find room) and have a drink with your food.

My beer of choice here is Old Speckled Hen. Delicious!
The drink to get here is 'The Recoil'... stellar drink:

The Recoil
1.5 oz good quality bourbon (we use Bulleit or Buffalo Trace, but any good one will do; Makers, Knob Creek, Old Grand Dad, etc.)
.5 oz St. Germain Elderflower liqueur
.5 oz Fresh Squeezed Lime Juice
Ginger Beer - Not ginger ale. Ginger beer is spicier and drier and makes a more balanced cocktail.

Read about it here:
http://sfist.com/2010/02/05/sfist_drinks_bloodhound.php
author: Anish B.

description:
3/5 strong

strong drinks. the atmosphere was the SOMA crowd, interesting decor inside. some arcade games towards the back, and it was definitely full of folks. nothing particularly striking about it though.
author: Alvin D.

description: Western dive bar. Such a great atmosphere and awesome decor! Good open space for larger groups. Good selection of beer on tap as well as spirits.
author: Elisha A.

description: Tasteful beer selections. Fair, legit, no nonsense bar tending and respectable mixology. Mind your business type of joint.
author: j. V.

description:
Went to a friend's exhibit at Back to the Picture and met up after viewing.  Was there on a Wednesday afternoon with my sister and the place was still pretty quiet.  We found two stools at the end of the bar and were pleased to see the assortment of quality cocktails they had to offer.  The bartender was very attentive, informative and friendly. 

My friend eventually arrived and we moved to the cool bar height tables by the window.  The ambiance is great as they had plenty of seating, pool tables and interesting decor.  It seems even if this place gets super packed you can still have room to get around.  

We had a couple rounds and I was pleased to see they use fresh ingredients and loved the mason jars used for the beer!

Glad I was introduced to the place and look forward to coming back with more friends!
author: Kim T.

description:
Came here for a Pork of July event - the event was awesome, but this review is for the bar.

This place makes strong ass drinks!!! That's all I gotta say. I had 3 drinks and was GONE. Woohoo!
author: Carol L.

description:
Dive bar in SOMA. I love this place! It is clean and roomy. Great place to have happy hour with a group of friends. 
Came here for Cinco de Mayo and a celebration for my friends' relay team accomplishment this past weekend. What better way to celebrate than to have a few good drinks at the Bloodhound. They have a pool table and 'Big Buck Hunter' video game! Tons of seats and tables. It reminded me of a hunting lodge in the middle of San Francisco. Prices are great and drinks are stiff. It is a comfortable place to just hang out.
author: Molly T.

description:
This might be in the middle of nowhere in SOMA but there's a few good reason why this place is one of the better bars in the city:

1. No B&T crowd = no posers
2. Pool table and big game hunting
3. Plenty of room and tables to chill to not feel claustrophobic
4. Great prices for drinks
5. Dog friendly (it is named after a breed after all)

Simply put, this bar epitomizes the true culture of SF and for that I salute you Bloodhound.
author: Ed L.

description:
This is a great local haunt. I rate the bar a 5 Sunday through Thursday but my rating drops on the weekend when the crowd roars in from everywhere. Dylan, Darren, Andy, Cortney and the rest of the team are an eclectic collection of bar-tending deliciousness. Prices are good especially in this city of up-charge, the atmosphere is fun and relaxed but don't be afraid to go in dressy (or in costume). 
Best nights are week nights when the bar staff have time to chat or make you something creative. Weekends make for a good scene but it can get really packed even to the point where they stop letting people inside.
Love that it is dog-friendly, love that Dylan likes to partner with local chefs to bring in food events, and if no pairings, feel free to order a pizza for delivery.
author: Julie H.

description:
Ahh the fantastic Bloodhound! Definitely one my favorite bars in the SOMA. Best Szerac I ever had was born here at this hip, laid-back, wooden cabin style bar. And their signature cocktails...  ::fingertips kiss:: Really, really good!

This bar can get pretty crowded, and you may find yourself planted in an open spot where there is a strong possibility that an unknowing pool stick will smack your face. But all can be forgivable as the many patrons I met here are very pleasant and friendly.

I still get a kick of the painted blackbirds hovering on the ceiling while enjoying my cocktail-in-a-jar. Western Spaghetti please!
author: Peter T.

description:
I like the look and feel of this bar. 

There's actually loads of seating areas that aren't lounge sofas, which I like. Everytime I sit on those lounge seats I think of all the grime people have wiped on it. (yuck) Anyways, they have bar style seating and tables that are not as occupied as one would think, it seems like everyone enjoys standing around, chit chatting with a beer in hand.

They've painted birds all over the ceiling. I commented to my friend that it was a really cute idea to which they responded "what? they're just stencils, I can even do it for you. ezpz" (followed by roll of eyeballs) but amateur me, I'm still very very impressed.

I ordered beer and shots of Jameson. I don't know how their cocktails are, but as usual beer is great!
author: Andrea K.

description:
basically this place is awesome.  you should go here.  i'm not even joking.

a friend of mine declared this Our Bar before ever going to it because it was conveniently located almost equal distance between our apartments (we wanted to be able to text each other and say, "let's meet at our bar tomorrow at 7p").  thankfully it turned out to be a good choice.

on our first visit we camped out at a table and drank ourselves into a silly little stuper.  the second time we visited was about 6 weeks later and the bartender remembered our drinks.  this thoroughly impressed me -- or frightened me because either he has a great memory or my friend and i were so drunk that we were memorable.  let's just go ahead and say the bartender had a great memory and maybe my friend and i were extremely awesome and hilarious.

in any case... this place is awesome.  mason jars for beer.  great decor.  bartenders who remember you.  i wish there were more late night places to eat after a few hours of drinking but that's not Bloodhounds fault.

now, if only my friend would stop traveling europe and come drink with me...
author: Lauren P.

description:
Huge fan of this place - No complaints!

Excellent and friendly staff.
Pool table (in good condition and felted regularly).
Good drinks and excellent beer on tap and affordable.
Comfortable crowd, more local not "sceney" (for folks that want to go out but don't want to feel like they're out).
It gets crowded on the weekends but there's always enough space
Beautiful design (love the birds on the ceiling)
Good juke box.

Again, no complaints!
author: Kara S.

description:
Oh Bloodhound...it's going to be a love-hate relationship between you and I...

and not because I don't enjoy my time there, I do...don't get me wrong...but someone always seems to get into trouble whenever my friends and I are there...

OK...so maybe it's just me who get's into trouble most of the time but I digress...

The wilderness cabin theme, along with the laid back atmosphere, coupled with the well-priced booze is a recipe for trouble...in a good way!

You always feel at home here. One of the best places to go to, to just hang out, chill and have a good time with friends.
author: Bernadette A.

description:
Bloodhound really strikes a great balance between a place with a complex cocktail menu and the type of place that you can go to just order a beer or a rum & coke.  All are welcome here and they staff the bar well and dish out the drinks quickly, even when it's busy.  

Drinks are a good price and the crowd is fairly friendly.  A perfect spot to grab a drink after work or before hitting up one of the local restaurants.
author: Rick D.

description:
Such an awesome bar from the decor, drinks, easy parking, and the people that go there. A coworker of mine says that it is her favorite bar and numerous friends have talked about what a cool spot it is. 

I went last night for a friend's birthday and had a great time. The cocktails are $9, but I believe they are a dollar cheaper during happy hour?? I could be wrong, but that is what someone told me yesterday evening. 

One of my favorite parts about the bar are the ravens (I believe that is what they are) that are painted onto the ceiling. So rad. 

Also, on Wednesday nights, the Chairman Bun food truck is outside and you can bring the tasty treats into the bar. SCORE! 

They have a full bar with a wide assortment of beers (bottled, draft, etc). I also noticed some of the ladies drinking wine and champagne.
author: Holly F.

description:
Bloodhound is a bar. Not a dive, not a cocktail lounge, not a club - it's a bar, awash in wood and leather and people drinking drinks. It's a bar that makes fine cocktails, has good beer on tap (served in Mason jars!) and an attractive crowd. Like most bars in the city, it can be a shit show on the weekends but I like to do my drinking early in the evening (or right before last call) on a weeknight anyway so that doesn't really bother me. 

Quick recap, as I tend to drift as I write these things: 

- Cool space: hey, is that a pool table?
- Great drinks: try the Ward 8 or Old Speckled Hen if you prefer beer
- Functional, informative website: need to know how to make a Ricky Riccardo or want to hear some Band of Horses? Check out http://www.bloodhoundsf.com/

Bloodhound may mean a trek across town for me but I know it also guarantees a good time.
author: phil h.

description:
A little bit of an older crowd than I'm used to, but I dig the vibe of this place. Strong, interesting drinks. 

Personally, I would not go out in this area just for this bar, but it's a really great option if you're in the area already or live nearby... definitely breathes some life into this part of SOMA.
author: Richa A.

description:
Best bar in SF for being so tastily flexible. And just plain tasty.

The Fella has guy-night here all the time. It's dark, lodge-like, and there's been a full-on pig-carving butcher session on more than one occasion for special events. The beers come in mason jars, there's a freakin' deer on the wall, and the wood paneling goes perfectly with the vibe.

That said, I've had after-work girls drinks here, too. It's quiet enough to gossip, and I've never had trouble finding a table for gabbing. The cocktails are pricey, but top-notch, with the Bloodhound and Ward 8 (bourbon, orange, lemon and grenadine) earning the top-tier spots for me. There's pretty artwork on the ceiling (painted black birds). Bacon-infused whiskey made an appearance once, and I keep waiting for it to come back.

A mild pain in the ass to get to, I must say. In what seems like the very middle of those enormous SoMa blocks, it's a ways off my closest bus route from work. But still well worth the effort.
author: Tara R.

description:
I ain't mad at cha...

I like your laidback vibe. 

I like your bartenders.

I like that you set a pig on fire during the Super Bowl and then served it extra crispy to us drunks.

Upscale for the neighborhood but to the rest of us, just appropriately dive-y enough.

Well done.
author: Susan L.

description:
Loved this place!  Great spot if you're looking for a chill bar, wanting to play a little pool and just sit back enjoying the music and the company.

It was crowded, but not ridiculous.  Decent selection of alcohol and if I recall correctly, price was moderate.  One compliant is the card minimum though.  No issue with the bartender, very attentive and seemed to handle crowd demand well. 

Another plus was they were passing out donuts last Friday night.  I shit you not, it's 1130 pm and when someone asks if you want a donut,  you obviously have to say yes.  

Of all the bars I've been to, I feel like the design here is really amazing; the light fixtures, bird scene above the pool table, rolling chairs, comfy booth, the liquor layout all done exceptionally well.  Obviously, the music matched the decor, eclectic and perfect to add to the ambiance.  Small compliant, no dance floor to fully take advantage of the playlist.
author: Laura H.

description: I love this bar, it has good vibes. It doesn't get too crowded and when it does, it has never been an issue to find a seat at the bar. The decor is very cool, i really enjoyed the black birds hanging from the ceilings. Check it out. But I believe there was a female bartender who mistaken my wording for sssssailor jerry please with an ice water. Other than that this place is a go to spot for a laid back date type of deal or any deal.
author: Sady C.

description:
This is my new favorite bar for a few reasons.

#1: The location. Easy parking, doable one-way streets from my place to there and back. It's also next to a parking lot that usually has a hot dog cart, which I don't usually partake in, but my friends have and fully support.

#2: The couches at the front. Cozy! You know how bar couches either are too stiff or too bouncy? These are perfect. I could (and have) spend many hours there.

#3: The bathroom. It's clean and well-maintained, a not-so-difficult thing, but one that bars in SF seem to have a problem with.

#4: The bar staff. They're on it (with the exception of a few times a couple of them have been too busy flirting with each other behind the bar--that's probably where that fifth star went). 

#5: The clientele. [Usually] pretty.
author: Rachel F.

description:
The 'cabin sheik' decor is a bigger contradiction than the Scottish Korean guy in the Skittles commercial. However, it makes this bar in the SOMA an interesting place to visit. A spacious dance floor, duck hunting video game, good size pool table and nice mixed cocktail will have you leaving satisfied. I came here on a Wednesday night, which was packed with the young professionals or hipsters of the SOMA. The scene was unpretentious , lively and definitely not a bad place to spend a Wednesday night..  I will be back.  

FYI, this place is animal friendly.  If you don't like animals or are allergic be weary of coming here.
author: James M.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite dive bars in SOMA

Long bar

Great prices

Great bartenders

Pool table in the back

Old-School arcades

Awesome
author: Charles C.

description: Good alcohol selection, great crowd, pool table, and jukebox! I like this place a lot and it's always an option for a chill night out with friends.
author: Julie T.

description:
This is my new neighborhood bar; its been almost a year, and in that time I've visited several times. i have to say, the doorman, the owner, and the bartenders are all super cool and extremely accommodating. Their is never a time when i feel unwelcome, or slighted because i am ignored (as can happen in any busy establishment). i was hoping this would be the way it turned out after some time, and happily surprised. 

Cheers to the management.
author: Adam X.

description:
There's a plastic gun pointed directly at my head, the bar girl has it pressed against her shoulder, digging into flesh. She's a lean woman, jet black hair and incandescent skin--a chest on show, shooting upwards. She wants me to know this won't hurt a bit, that I had it coming, brought it upon myself. Drawing her legs together, she straightens her stance, pulling inches for fear. An eye closes as she focuses in, the remaining lens wildly placed, honing in on my quaking boots. 

"Run to your grave, kid," she insists.

And with the click of a trigger she has me beeped. An assumed death by way of flashing screens. Player two, deceased.
author: Marc M.

description:
If Tennessee were hip, it would be Bloodhound.

interior is clean and classy enough to take a lady friend, yet familiar enough for when the redneck side of your family comes to town.

enjoy good alcohol, hustle the pool table, and bust a cap in deer, all under one roof.  very relaxing and fun environment.

PS there is a $20 card-minimum, ATM inside as well though...
author: eric f.

description:
If bloodhound was a pheasant field, and each of the happy-hour drinkers - of reasonable to strapping good looks, all from different identifiable neighborhoods - was such a fat regal bird, then a hunter's best friend would make easy work here.  And so the name Bloodhound is appropriate.  It's teeming indeed, but unfortunately, the clientele don't scatter like birds when you intimate you'd like to get a drink at the crowded bar.

Rustic, hip, densely-populated, and they serve up works of bourbon and rye art.  I recommend the "recoil."
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Finally, a reliably awesome bar in SOMA for all occasions! Football fan? They show the NFL ticket starting at like 10am. Bar crawl? You might find it hard to leave... unless you're female and REALLY have to pee. Happy hour? There's a decent crowd every day of the week, but if it's quiet just play a round of pool at the table in the back!

Get the Old Speckled Hen beer. Trust me, it has even converted non-beer drinkers and don't be fooled by what looks like a bad pour; it's supposed to be that way. 

Warning: DO NOT let your date order you mixed drinks here - they are way stronger than you realize (but he probably does).
author: Shannon B.

description: My dog Rupert is always the belle of the ball whenever we go here, and he loves it.  They allow dogs, which gets points in my book.  The only other place I know that allows dogs is the 500 Club.  It has a cool, hipster vibe.  I love coming here on any nights except Thurs, Fri, or Sat, when it gets way too loud to hear yourself think, much less anyone else talk.  The drinks are creative and always good.  Nice draft beer selection too - largers, ales and dark beer.
author: Steve S.

description:
DIGGIN the rustic saloon vibe: 

-Antler chandeliers 
-Beer muggin 
-Tall wood tables n stools, leather nooks 

Great spot for any vice - make it your own. Quick drink or big party night...works either way :)
author: Charlene A.

description: Crowded, and definitely "hipster chic" as far as decor and crowd go (antlers, seriously?), but they have great taps and they definitely know what to do with their bourbon. If it weren't always so stuffy in there, it'd be a perfect local bar. I came here just yesterday to see the Giants game (woohoo, 9-0!) and I was shocked that the bar wasn't overflowingly packed. There was even a sketchy (but delicious looking) pizza stand out front. They were baking pizza in a Weber barbecue! I've also seen the Chairman Bao bun truck parked out here, and of course there's Chez Spencer just next door. So if you like to get your drink on while you get your yuppie food carts on, this is your place.
author: Josh K.

description:
I liked it!

It reminded me of a lodge I'd go to in Tahoe after a full day of skiing, but who am I kidding:  I'm a wuss now and haven't gone skiing in years.

Lots of wood all over the place, plenty of couches, $9 special cocktails that were really good (I liked the ginger one the best) with fast/friendly bartenders without a hint of attitude. And were those antlers I saw on the wall?

Best part of the nite was when we started smelling the bacon covered hot dogs being grilled just outside the place... yummay.
author: Nenette Y.

description: Gorgeous. I love the space, the tables, the lights over the bar, the birds on the ceiling. I also became a fan of the pisco punch. Damn. Two of those and I was ready to deal with the night. I hope to be back!
author: April T.

description:
As Gretchen B. accurately noted, "hunt or be hunted." For those of you looking for a meet market, look no further. This place was crawling with lurkers, stalkers and creepers hoping to score. Granted, the crowd was overall good looking, but I felt confused about where I was in the city. Not quite as douchy as the Marina but definitely had a bit of that tone. 

Positives are the bar is beautiful and clean, drinks are served strong and relatively cheap AND they have buckhunter, my new favorite game. I'd check out happy hour if I came back to see if it's a bit more mellow than a Saturday night.
author: Shannon C.

description:
I don't really go for blood, I go for booze.

I am a boozehound.

We stepped in here after Pride because we were tired of drinking with people and The Castro didn't seem a good place to wind down. After partying with the gays and their friends en masse, I didn't know if I could keep up with them up on their stomping grounds.

But this was a pleasant surprise. Nice raw woods made up the fixtures of the place, chic interior, lots of character. Lots of window space take advantage of the SOMA neighborhood and the place was nice to duck away.

There was a fun shooting game in the back. I think the sight of me holding a gun was slightly pathetic.

Oh, Jolene.

But down to the drink. Off the cute bartender's suggestion, I did the Peach Blossom from the menu. Watching him mix it was almost like having breakfast. I got slightly turned on watching a cute man pouring honey.

It was perfect. Crisp, slightly sweet, and a good tang. And straight up in a martini glass.

I am not kin to SOMA, but if I was in the hood again - this would be a definite stop.
author: Kim D.

description:
A-mazing drinks here. This place caused me for the first time in a long time to drink not beer for reasons other than lack of beer (they do have beer and the selection is decent for a non-beer bar).

I can't remember the names of the drinks we had, but everything was made incredibly well. Great ingredients, amazing selection of different bourbons and whiskies, and everything mixed just right. It's amazing when you find a place that really knows what they're doing and this place is one of those.

It feels a bit hipstery but that can be forgiven for the awesome drinks, tasty 4505 chicharrones, and fun bartenders.
author: Josh H.

description:
I dont know what to think of this place. Super weird crowd. I've never seen so many sexually ambiguous people in my life. This could be a plus since it was definitely good people watching. Lots of hipsters. Lots of thin suspenders.

The bar itself has a nice pool table and buck hunter, which is great. The interior did feel a bit forced and seemed baron and forced. Drinks were ok. Ginger ale drink looked really good.
author: Mike I.

description:
What a ceiling.. what a cool ceiling..

Popped in for a sunny day sunset toast. Service was swell, cocktail options abundant (applause to the stocking of fresh mint, you're a class above), but the main thing is, nice ceiling! On a canvas of off-white paint, there are aggregates of stenciled birds. To me, it really makes the space, which otherwise is (to my untrained eye) just the avg bar set-up. Ah SF design nerds: Props to the bar that makes one intermittently look upward n' dream of seascape flutter.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I love the look and feel of this place!  The lighting, mason jars, drinks...it's fun.  I had a few Sidecars and they were yummy.  Not all bars know how to make a great Sidecar and I feel like it's such a simple drink.  The crowd is also pretty diverse.  You get a little bit of everything, it's very San Francisco.

I've only been to this bar once but I plan on bringing friends back.
author: Becca L.

description: To the skinny guy who has something to prove behind the bar. You work Tuesdays for a reason. I am always a good, respectful patron and to have someone attack me from behind the bar with no cause is insane. Good luck, not going back.
author: Greg B.

description:
5 stars is perfect so consider this a 4.5 star rating. Very mixed crowd which was good so you don't feel out of place, but something felt missing so, no 5 stars.

PROS:
-Drinks are cheap!
-Ambiance is creative (little more could be done I to really drive it home)
-Food guys at front door that will bring your food in for you (huge +)
-Quick service and friendly bartenders
author: Jonathan M.

description:
"A nice bar trying to be a dive bar trying to be a nice bar." - Mikey

Good prices, good service, and you get to drink beer out of a jar.
author: Paul K.

description:
Let's say its a wednesday and you really need a drink 'cuz you're kind of an alchoholic. Enter Bloodhound...WIN!

Mid-week, this place is pretty chill, but not romantically quiet. Nice vibe inside where you have a neato blend of sportsman kitch mixed with some low lit candelight tables. Wait, that's not a blend at all, its a polar opposite...ha! Fear not, the deer antlers hanging from the roof and the sports on the TV out-manify the girlitude of the candlelights.

Comfy couches (yay!), nice, helpful, chill staff. The taps at this place are pretty solid - its tough to go wrong with anything they have up there. There are some belgium bottles they have too if you start asking. Some people may drop the rip that you don't have an infinite selection of beer here, but seriously...sometimes its nice to not have to choose from a laundry list of weird european names. 

Liquor and cocktail selection is similar to the beer selection. You aren't going to get crazy Bourbon and Branch or Alembic style cocktails here, but they will be classic and made well. No weird funky shit - just light citus and whiskey and the like. My favs!

I'll be back to drink som'more here.
author: Sean C.

description:
I give this place a 3.5.  I appreciate that the management followed up on my review to assure me that Bloodhound has never served food...  I've returned, and the place has grown on me a bit - hence the 0.5-star upgrade.

Summary:
- good drinks (esp. the Recoil) at a reasonable price
- good friends (but BYO of course), friendly crowd
- could be more dive-y for my taste (so it's not so super crowded)
- still wish I could order food, tho I appreciate that I can bring food in
author: Fontane L.

description: I love this place!  Discovered Bloodhound a couple months back after a show at the Bill Graham and fell in love.  When I booked a room for New Years weekend at America's Best Value Inn and saw they were in the same building I was ecstatic and ended up coming to Bloodhound every night.  The bartenders know how to make a drink and the drinks list is fantastic.  They've got a nice pool table in the back as well as Buck Hunter.  And the decor is rad.  Blackbirds on the ceiling, neat old pictures on the wall.  They're also dog friendly and there were dogs roaming around on a couple of the occasions I was in there, which is perfectly fine by me.  I'm a huge fan of Bloodhound.
author: Alex F.

description: A really interesting bar, with rustic chic decor and intriguing special cocktails. Also, they happen to allow any sort of dogs in their bar. As a vet student, I appreciated this enormously. The dogs were in some ways more interesting than the bar itself :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
A hunting lodge for the SOMA crowd

Take a comfortable dive bar and mash it together with a hunting lodge and you have Bloodhound. Pretty straightforward bar with high quality bourbon and spirits, a few meaty salty snacks consisting of Whisky Sticks from The Fatted Calf and Chicharrones from Ryan Farr's 4505 meats and a nice open feel to it, unless it's packed like it typically is wed.-sat. This bar has tons of open space, some cozy high-back chairs and 2 couches you could get lost in on a cold sunday afternoon while the rain beats down outside. 

If you're looking for sporting, as any good hunting club should offer, there are 2-3 flat panel TVs that are tuned to sports, a nice pool table in back with plenty of shooting space and, of course, what's quickly becoming the new 'Golden Tee' for modern bars, the video game 'Big Game Hunter' where you can show off your marksmanship skills and take down an electronic deer or two.

Bloodhound features some 'whole pig' and other special cooking events from local butchers and chefs and I'm told that San Francisco's Bull Moose Hunting Club meets here the first tuesday of each month for socializing and planning hunting outings.
author: Derek D.

description: I usually don't review bars but I thought the drinks here were pretty good. The bartenders were sort of busy but were also very friendly. I usually get a cold stare and then silence when I order at the bar but I thought the bartenders here were pretty friendly if you stop to talk for a minute. The drinks were very good. I think my friends and I would recommend their cocktail named "recoil".
author: Amber R.

description: Don't know why I never knew about this place. A pretty chill late night spot, spacious enough to waltz around the room but enough of a crowd to create a sort of buzz. The drinks were pretty well crafted if I remember correctly. Not too sweet, not too plain. Pool table, clean bathrooms, across the street from Cat Club.
author: Farah S.

description: If you ever fancied yourself making an excellent Portlandia character, then this is the bar for you!  Bloodhound oozes rustic chic with "put a bird on it" ceilings and drinks served in mason jars.  I don't think I'd really make it in Portlandia, though Bloodhound's good beer selection made up for it.
author: Ashley G.

description: Good beers on tap. Great old-fashion drinks. Friendly bartender. Old Western Saloon decor. Excellent happy hour deals.
author: Daniel K.

description:
What a find!  Came to Bloodhound last night to celebrate a SF anniversary for a friend whose lived here two years.  I'll definitely be coming back.

The things I love about Bloodhound:

Awesome hunting lodge decor - I almost felt it should've been in Disneyland's Frontier Land.  But it was just short of being kitschy which made it perfect

Beer in mason jars - Very unique...and what a great selection of beer they had!  But I wondered if the mason jars were to distract us from the fact that you're still paying $5 for a beer but not quite getting a pint?  At least that's how it seemed to me.

Jukebox - Awesome selection of music.  Thanks to Andrei Z, we had a great time picking out songs and playing "name that artist" (or drink) whilst doing so.

Pool table/duck hunt - I love having entertainment in a bar....also played in to the lodge feel.

This place is open with a lot of windows (which provided much entertainment through the night...naked man, man brushing his teeth, women walking a pygmie goat on a leash).  Just across from Terroir, you can do wine one night and beer the next.  

I'll definitely be back for more Bloodhound....
author: Melanie N.

description:
Normal bar. Came here for a kickball shindig. The "open" bar was only open till the tab was met. 

Lame.
author: Pamela R.

description: Love Bloodhound!  It's my local neighborhood bar and I always enjoy stopping in for a beer.  They have fancier drinks and wide variety of beers to suit everyone's tastes.  Atmosphere is laid back and relaxed and there is always a diverse mix of people.  Only negative is that it can get crowdy and pretty noisy but hey, that's the sign of a good bar i guess!
author: Randi M.

description:
I would like to give this place 3.5 stars..
Great decor, not really a dive bar but not quite a lounge....Maybe an upscale dive bar???
I mean, maybe, this place does deserve 4 stars. Great western/hunter theme, antler chandliers, and buck hunter in the back. Good music to top it off, the drinks could probably have been a bit cheaper, but its San Francisco, so thats to be expected. 
Try the Ward 8 (bourbon, orange lemon, and grenadine) or the signature Bloodhound (pretty sure you'll enjoy both)
author: Jenn H.

description: A sports bar with free wifi, and quite possibly the best Bloody Mary in SF?  What's not to like?  (Well, I can think of one thing: it can get pretty cold in here on a January afternoon.  Other than that, it's great.)
author: Zain K.

description: Favorite bar we've been to in San Francisco.  Not only do they have Old Speckeled Hen on tap, but the atmosphere with a unique rustic theme is a refreshing change.  The night we went, there was plenty of space, no yelling just to converse with your friends, and the bar tenders were quick and pleasant.  If you are in SOMA, check this one out!
author: Kim K.

description:
Hunt or be hunted.

Bloodhound is a pretty awesome bar.  A manly-sexy-hunting vibe as other have mentioned.  This is what a lot of dive bars would be like if the others... you know... swept the floor, or cleaned the bathroom.  This feels like a place you can have an unpretentious beer in a jar without having to dress down for the occasion (perhaps pre- or post- dinner at Heaven's Dog around the corner).

The cocktails here were good - exactly how they were described on the menu (the bloodhound was a little sweet for me - I liked the recoil).  The star of the show though, might be the beer.  Everything we tried was super fresh on tap and the bartenders were excellent with recommendations.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
A bigger, more upscale version of the Bigfoot Lodge on Polk that seems to attract an interesting, mixed crowd. Strong drinks, cool ceiling, good seating options. 

HOWEVER.... 

(1) They had a $20 credit card minimum, which is a violation of Visa and MasterCard merchant agreements. Merchants' Visa and MasterCard agreements DO NOT PERMIT merchants to charge a minimum for credit card use. 

(2) They have installed a partition in the men's bathroom that hides the urinal from view when the door opens but makes the bathroom inaccessible to wheelchairs. I brought this to the co-owner's attention, but I have not been back to see whether they've done anything to fix the problem. 

Someone at Yelp needs to change "wheelchair accessible" from yes to no. 

Boo on Bloodhound.
author: katie m.

description: Have been here about a half a dozen times with the wife after work during the week.  Got there about 5 and left around 9 each time.  The place does get packed on Friday's but isn't that why you go.  The crowd is starting to get just a tad hipsterish but isn't  all of San Francisco.  There are still enough normal people in there to make it tolerable.  I like it because the drinks are very good if not great, and I have never had a problem with any of the bartenders that other posters have had.  Show a little patience when they are busy and tip big on the first order and try smiling and saying thank you, they will remember you!
author: Christopher K.

description:
I came here last week for a friend's birthday party and literally 3 out of 4 patrons were there for her... so I perhaps wasn't able to get the best scope of the scene. BUT, the decor is cool and the drinks are cheap. Despite being a bit crowded, the place is actually pretty big and you can choose to lounge on couches, hang at the bar, or play pool in the back. The only big downside is that there's no practical system for smoking. I personally don't smoke but all my friends were so I got caught in the hubbub. You have to leave through the front door and hope that the doorman remembers you or else he'll make you get back in line! Also, it was raining and there were no overhangs or designated smoking area... Oh also the jam jars they serve beer in are really cool.

One of many hip bars in up-and-coming SOMA.
author: Alexander M.

description:
Long bars make me happy.  A long line of stools begging to be sat upon, with bartenders at the ready - it's just a lovely sight.  And the decor - post-modern hunting lodge? - works.  If they just had a fireplace, I would probably never leave.

I came here for a Yelp event, and returned a few weeks later to check it out again.  As with most bars, early is best, and after-work hours give you the place to yourself before the crowds come.  I love a bartender who can make a great bourbon or Scotch cocktail, and they make them well here.  The bacon-infused bourbon is a fun conversation piece, but go with one of the other ones for real flavor.

In lieu of a chest-burning whiskey, a Mason Jar of Old Speckled Hen is a great option.

Definitely worth stopping in to wet your whistle - early or late is probably best, to avoid the amateur/chode-potential factor.
author: Liz S.

description:
I've only seen this place get super crazy right after The Strokes played at Outside Lands.  The band came to hang out at this bar apparently--something we weren't anticipating as it's no where near GG Park.  They brought an insane group of people with them and dominated the bar.  They also opened up their tab for a couple of hours, so no complaints there. 

They make a great mint julep (random to drink regularly, I know).  And the decor and pool table in the back makes this a really chill place to hang out.
author: Alex H.

description:
I don't know that I'm Bloodhound's target demographic, since I seldom drink cocktails, but my friends definitely are, since they relish cocktails, the more old-school or complicated to make, the better. 
My first visit to Bloodhound was for a meat-centric event that featured butchers breaking down pig, lamb and goat right before your eyes. That was magical indeed.  My 2nd visit was at the end of a Friday night spent with a half-dozen good friends, bouncing around to good drinking spots on Folsom St.  Friends had their fancy cocktails, I had a Sierra Nevada Southern Hemisphere Harvest, served in a pint Mason jar.  Cute enough, and the presence of chill dogs hanging out was a bonus.  I know this place is uber-hipstery, but I've never had anything but good times and great service here, so Bloodhound is just all right with me.
author: Melissa L.

description: Lots of room to mill about, pretty decent beer selection, and always lots of interesting folks around. But all of that aside, the most delicious reason to come is the Recoil cocktail. It is my joy as well as my undoing. Cheers!
author: Chelsea B.

description: Excellent cocktails but its your typical grimy, crowded bar. Good for work outings.
author: Miri L.

description:
Nice bar. Nice staff.

Some tool of a patron stole my jacket the Friday of January 15.

So watch you stuff here.
author: Cris R.

description:
I liked Bloodhound.  The bar with all its alcoholic glory was beautiful.  Huge space, decent seating, pool table, clean bathrooms, nice bartenders (on a Wednesday night).  There was a great crowd there tonight, quite possibly 80% of them were couchsurfers.  It did get a little stuffy but once they opened the windows, it was a lot better.  Plus they played music from the XX.  Love them =)

P.S  Strict about alcohol outside.
author: Walerz B.

description:
When I think of a great bar in SF to go to that doesn't require me having to dress up or anyone in my party to abide by a dresscode - I think of Bloodhound. This place holds a special place in my heart given the fact that it encompasses many winning factors for the Bay Area patrons.

1. 4pm Happy Hour - a dollar off regular prices. We arrived yesterday promptly at 3:43pm after our SF Food Bank volunteer event via @Boobs4Food. We were thirsty. Very thirsty. Since the doors weren't open, we went to the liquor store on the next block and downed a couple beers to quench our thirst. Point being, they open at 4pm. If you arrive earlier, you know where to go. 

2. Quality environment that makes you want to stay all afternoon - I love the decor, the painted birds on the ceiling, all the Hunting theme mumbojumbo. The excellent longbar with tons of comfy barstools.

3. The Bartenders - they know their stuff and they make great drinks. Whether you want beer or liquor - they pretty much have it all. I tried the "Dusty Road" yesterday as Anthony cranked out a few for our party. Bulliet Bourbon + Bundaberg Ginger Beer + wedge of lemon. Delish. I'll be getting that all the time now if I'm not getting 1 of their many beers on tap. Love the La Chouffe!!

4. $3 Chicharrones Bar Snacks - the perfect compliment to a jar-ful of beer or a strong cocktail is a bag of these swine-a-licious rinds courtesy of Ryan Farr's 4505 Meats. Tasty, crispy, dusted with a spicy goodness and clearly indulgent. Grab a bag on your next visit. 

5. Closely located off the freeway - whether you live in town or BNT - it's a quick getaway to soothe your weekday stress with strong libations, kind service and good company. 

Bloodhound is definitely where it is at.
author: Jessica C.

description: WORST bar service ever! And on a Wednesday night! I was ignored by both bartenders for over 10 minutes. I can get a drink faster at Zeitgeist--even on Saturday night. Bloodhound is too loud to have any kind of conversation. Pretentious, overpriced, and loaded with yuppies--too much like the Marina. Skip it!
author: Anne M.

description:
I liked that they had beer in mason jars.  I like the spray painted stencil birds on the ceiling.  
I didn't like the wack douchemobile clientele made up of 40% fratboys and 40% marina bimbos.
It's unfortunate that another cool dive bar with local flavor (cassidy's) has been transformed into another chain bar gentrification station.
author: Matt N.

description: Very comfortable bar with good seating on most nights. But it does get busy so be prepared to stand. They have one drink with Bulleit bourbon and st germain that's amazing. I try to go as often as I can!
author: Jenny M.

description: I love this bar!!! Best Manhattans in town, bartenders always super friendly. My favor day is Sunday afternoon when you have all the locals in and a friendly bartender Amanda. Cant wait to go back!!
author: L N.

description:
Right, so this place is as creepy as it looks. Namely because it begs the questions:

1. What the hell is this?? A high end white trash bar? What?
2. Um..this is Soma right? Does IT know it's in Soma?
3. .. uh..3's a little racist so I'm going to withhold this one. But trust me, it makes this place even weirder. 

That said, I didn't answer your question did I. Yes, this place is definitely worth checking out. I love the unfamiliar vibe because it's something different, and I love the lost soul/evil genius who thought Soma was the right venue for it. 

Come here for a beer, a casual game of pool and a very different vibe. 

ps - The boy who lost the game of pool to me still has to make good on his bet and play the next game in his boxers. You know who you are.
author: Shreya C.

description:
It's dark, smelly, and reminds me of Gaston's lair in Disney's "Beauty and the Beast," but I dig the pretty bird patterns on the ceiling. 

Drinks are decent tasting, and decently priced for SF. My friends and I had fun here.
author: Jen L.

description:
Came here for some drinks-- loved the atmosphere and the decor, however I think came to early in the eve and the crowd was random.

I think it could be a lot more fun had we come later in the evening, but we were just after the happy hour crowd and just before the bar crowd so I don't think we got the full vibe of this place.

I did enjoy it though--It was nice to be able to find a table to sit and not be ass to elbow with five million of your soon to be closest friends.

I think I need to come back and give it another go.
author: Lu E.

description:
I got to check out The Bloodhound bar last night (it opens next week), and this is going to be a good one, guys. The place is built to look like a modern hunting lodge with walls of beautiful raw wood slats fitted together in interesting ways, chandeliers of woven antlers, redwood slab tables and a ceiling alive with stencils of small birds flitting about.

There's a long bar on the side for sittin' and drinkin', a small lounge in the front and most importantly, a pool table in the back for shootin' some stick. Dylan and Mike are true visionaries, and there's no doubt this will become a good neighborhood bar for friendly Soma folk. No DJ to ruin the mellow vibe and no dance floor -- just a simple artisan cocktail menu, as well as some obscure exotic and local brews. 

Find me here bolted to the bar stool, whisky in one hand, pool stick in the other, singing along to the jukebox tunes.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Came here for a pint of Guiness and a meeting this evening. Didn't know they had that many skulls in San Francisco--Thought they disappeared with SF Gun Exchange. They like their antlers and horns here. Kind of reminds me of a pint-sized British Bankers Club, where I bartended about 5 years ago.

They don't have the big Cape buffalo heads the way they did at the BBC in Menlo Park, but they are giving the Menlo Park bar and grill a run for the money with a few mounted kudu skulls on the walls. 

I would have given it 4 stars for a nice place to hang out and enjoy a Brit-style stout or mixed drink. But...the bartender for the evening didn't know what loud meant on the volume control. Almost got blown out the door by a song I can't even remember what it was other than I remember hearing it in high school--not something I wanted blasting in my ear while I'm trying to talk with a group of people.

Would like to try the pub food next time.
author: Cork G.

description:
Good beer served in mason jars, awesome bartender, laid back but not divey.  I'm a big fan of dives but sometimes you want a place a little nicer and the bloodhound fits the bill.

I agree with Jared Z that if it was in the Mission I'd give it another star.
author: Jason S.

description:
Damnit.

One month after opening, and the place is crawling with douche-bags.

Why the hell can't we get a decent bar in the SoMa that doesn't get overrun with striped-shirt-wearing assholes who work in the Financial Center?

Is it really too much to ask?
author: James C.

description:
So I've walked and drive past this bar so many times I've lost count.  But I finally found the occasion to actually make it inside after dinner in the neighborhood.

It's a rustic theme with antlers and hunter motif spread throughout the bar (down to the entertaining hunting video where you score points for shooting buck but lose if you accidentally hit a doe - who comes up with these?!)

It was kicking on a Saturday night and the place exuded a laidback, casual feel that I enjoyed.  The bartenders seem pretty experienced in their craft (they were making some intricate cocktails in addition to our straight up drinks).  A little on the pricier side for drinks but not that bad.

Overall, not a bad place to chill with your friends.
author: F. P.

description:
I was a little concerned when I noticed a Bauer bus parked in front of Bloodhound.  I wasn't in the mood for a party bus kind of crowd but luckily, they cleared out pretty soon after we got there.

The space was much bigger than I thought it would be with plenty of places to sit or stand around.  I liked the texture of the seating along the front area  and the walls, now that I think about it.  It was lodge-y and rustic without being too over the top.

I enjoyed my La Chouffes while listening to the random selection of music from the jukebox and chatting about nonsense.  I'm starting to feel at home around here.
author: Seong P.

description: Decent bar. Super crowded on a Friday night with an ummm, i dunno, trendy, hipster kinda sorta crowd. Not really my style. Plus, some dude was kinda stalking me and it gave me the heebie jeebies.
author: Christina S.

description:
Way back in the day when I lived in SoMa, getting filthy on Natoma, Bloodhound was called Cassidy's, and I was a lot thinner and more innocent and pure because I'd never been near Double Dutch on a Friday night. So you can imagine that when the aforementioned was highly touted as a selling point, as a reason to come and not listed first as a reason to avoid this place, I was a deeply, deeply troubled.

It was a birthday what brought me here. A good friend, only months from marriage in fact and celebrating some god-awfully high numbered trip around the sun. And since birthdays are mandatory I went. And it was okay. Really.  It was absolutely not a shit show that collapsed upon its own gaudiness and drove you away in despair.

Aside from an unfortunate encounter at the jukebox where my music-snobbishness was unappreciated, (which is really my fault, I mean, I have to learn to let people be, who cares if they like radio R&B and Top 40 rap, I mean really?) everything was extremely not awful. My flight reflex was never triggered. Not once the whole night.

The room is really nice and  the layout is much better than before. I was there on a Friday night and so yes it was full of people dressed for a club and guys were 'sharking' - but that's to be expected. 

Because remember people, the alternative to Bloodhound, is not some Platonic ideal of the perfect bar where the bartenders are cool, and no one is on the verge of puking after too many Jaeger bombs. No, no, no. The alternative to Bloodhound is the Holy Cow. 

Yeah. So just shut it, and be thankful for what you've got.
author: Olu J.

description:
um yea, i like this place. it's a special day when i walk into a bar in sf and don't feel 10 years older than everyone. i'm not that old people, but respectably in my mid-30s now and there's nothing more annoying than being the 30-something in a bar full of 25 year olds. was i really that young and annoying? probably not, because i'm me, but still. we walked in around 8:30 and the place was still happening from happy hour. i'm sure it's madness right after work.

this is not a dive bar. those who are calling it one have clearly never been to a dive bar. dive bars do not have decor themes, matching chairs, or toilets you can actually sit on. most importantly, dive bars do not have balanced and classic cocktails. bloodhound has all of these things. 

the decor is kind of eery-fabulous, i'm always a fan of an antler chandelier and taxidermy is growing on me, tho we kind of stole that from the seattle folks. i was slightly mesmerized by that creepy-cool painting on the ceiling of fluttering birds. the music was great as well. i appreciate a bar that delivers consistently in all of these areas, and they brought it home for me with my cocktail. i had the boulevardier. smooth rye with a bite of lemon peel. yum. 

i'd go here anytime.
author: rachel p.

description: Very trendy, very loud, but great beers and cocktails. Nice to jump in for a bit and be overwhelmed by the ambience.
author: Craig W.

description:
Bloodhound is a Pac-NW bar lifted by its foundations & transported magically from Portland to San Francisco. I absolutely love the Lodge-like atmosphere, although the prices are quite steep ($9 for a cocktail? Christ!), which is very un-loggerly of them.

This is the perfect place for sensitive bearded men in flannel shirts & nouveau chunky black-rimmed glasses to play an ironic game of Big Buck Hunter underneath an antler chandelier. In a way, it's almost fitting for Bloodhound to have landed here, in the footprint of the much beloved punk & metal dive that preceded it. The frontier-like atmosphere of the place is fitting for this particular as-of-yet-unvogued corner of SOMA.

Sure, people may still be pooping in the alley next to the bar every night, but today's human poop is tomorrow's fertilizer (see: Hayes Valley, The Mission). A few years from now, the whole neighborhood will likely be full of high end cocktail bars.

With a name like Bloodhound, I'd expected a grapefruit juice & vodka frou frou-type experience, but the vibe was is great. I have a hunch it'll be around for awhile.
author: Pete J.

description: my best friend and i were in the city and stupidly parked in a tow away zone... so we had to go find the place that had our car and get it. While wandering around, I really had to use the restroom. Like, no joke! So, we started walking around and stumbled upon this bar. Much to our surprise, it was actually really lively at 6pm (guessing all the business people there for an after work drink). The atmosphere is chill, good music, different types of crowd, not just business or hipsters. Free wifi was a plus and our beers were only $3 each! we had Pacifico since they didnt have Corona, which isnt too bad. All we wanted was a chill place to relax, use the restroom (VERY clean, too bad only one stall) and have a beer. Great place to stumble upon. Definelty coming back if im ever in the city in the area again
author: Rosie S.

description: This bar is great, probably one of my new favorites, i will definitely be back, it would get 6 stars if only it was in the mission, amazing selection of beers, from all over including some English and Belgian beers on tap! on tap! super nice bartenders, and a really thoughtful design for the decor.
author: Jared Z.

description:
Went here again last night for a farewell happy hour with co-workers and still loved it!

It got a little packed this time, especially with a reelection party happening simultaneously as we surfaced up the latest office gossip.

The Pimms Cup was still so very delicious and everyone else seemed to love their bloody mary's enough that they indulged in two or three.  Three cocktails and it only came up to 15 dollars.  Not too shabby.

It's still has it's charm, and I did notice the fun hunting shooting game in the back.  But I would've much rather shot the bartender and took him home with me.  MmMm.

Next time I'll wear my camo gear.

Happy Hunting!
author: Vince S.

description: Love this local bar not simply because it's within walking distance, but for the helpful service by the bartenders and chill, non-pretentious folks that go there, yes, even the ones that bring their dogs.
author: M. O.

description:
I'm really happy that bloodhound moved into the hood..  They have a pool table and.. big buck hunter which is like completely appropriate for the decor, being hunting lodge-ish and all.  Man, I do love to hunt me some bucks (of the video game variety).  The buck hunter thing is huge on the east coast, and I'm happy to see that it's (maybe) starting to take hold here.  I mean, shootin' and drinkin' go so naturally together, don't they?

The drinks are well made, and the fact that their namesake drink, the bloodhound #1 contains a healthy dose of campari warms the cockles of my heart, which I think is a good thing.  If you like beer, definitely try the old speckled hen, which is a tasty, tasty beer.  

One night, the friendly bartender explained to me the whole socio-political makeup of Irish Whiskeys: apparently Jamesons is the catholic one, and Bushmills is the protestant one.  Then, he promptly poured us the whiskey that was non-affiliated.. I can't remember what it was, so it must have been good.  See? I learned something.

I'm not sure what the other reviews are thinking since sizewise, the bar is plenty big for San Francisco.. and as for it smelling, um.. I guess they were never here before, nor do they smell any of the other bars in this city (especially the one in the mission that rhymes with assanova.. great bar, but man, that place smells awful.)  

Oh, and +1 star for being open EVERY NIGHT of the week.  Too many places in this hood seem to think that (a) people aren't here past 6pm (ahem, new pho place on 9th) or (b) people don't go out on mondays or tuesdays (I'm looking at you, Rocco's)..  So, I'm super happy that bloodhound is open every night, like a proper place in a city should be.

Anyway, welcome to the hood, bloodhound folks..  I'll be seein you a plenty, methinks.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Love the hunting theme of this place. I usually don't order off the drink menu, but this one is not to be ingored. Had one with bourbon, ginger beer, lime juice and elderberry flower liquer. Top notch.
author: Matt S.

description: Cool spot for a drink if you are in the area.  They have some couches up front and tables toward the back of the place.  Casual and fun place
author: Dilly M.

description:
Soft opening last night. Definitely loved the vibe of the bar with the reclaimed barn wood and rustic lighting. The smell of saddle leather seems to permeate (in a good way) and contrary to the awkward layout that was Cassidy's, the bar is really cozy and inviting. 

They've got a great selection of whiskeys and beers which totally suits the lodge atmosphere. As a beer guy, it's great to see more and more bars taking care to feature interesting beers on their list and these guys had some phenomenal stuff like La Chouffe, Red Rocket and Duchesse De Bourgogne. They just happen to have Firestone DBA on tap as well, which is certainly a big plus! 

The owners are really nice guys and certainly have a knack for creating unique atmosphere in their places. This stretch of the city has certaubky been lacking for good bars. Not clubs, not dives, not gay leather spots - just good, neighborhood bars. The only thing really missing is a fireplace...
author: Brandon B.

description:
The B-hound can be quite inconsistent... but most of it's not really their fault.  I'm talking more about the crowd/ambience.  I've been a few times.  Once, the place was goin off the hook, good diverse crowd, hip hop jammin over the speakers - it was likely the best place to be out that night!  Another time, it was d-e-a-d as a doornail at 10pm on a Thursday night so we had to walk ourselves across the Street to 1984 at Cat Club.
